    • Randy M says:
      January 22, 2020 at 1:50 pm

      If you aren’t dripping fluids at the moment, you’re probably healthier than the average person a doctor sees.

    • pilord says:
      January 22, 2020 at 5:58 pm

      You probably also don’t look particularly inflamed / puffy, and you might not have bags under your eyes either. It’s easy to notice once you start looking for it, and can be good indications of dietary and sleep health.

  48. HowardHolmes says:
    January 22, 2020 at 12:06 pm

    Some thoughts on preferences and willpower.

    At any time there is only one thing you prefer doing, and you do it.
    It takes no willpower to do what one prefers to do.
    Claiming to lack willpower is an attempt to take credit for preferences you do not have.
    Claiming to prefer doing other than you are doing is an attempt to avoid taking responsibility for your actions.

    • JayT says:
      January 22, 2020 at 12:23 pm

      I don’t see how claiming to lack willpower would be an attempt to take credit for preferences you don’t have. When someone claims that, they are fairly explicitly saying that they can’t stop themselves from taking their preference, even if the other options might lead to more long term benefits. When people say “I lack the willpower to eat a salad when there are hamburgers available” they aren’t trying to claim that they would prefer a salad, they are acknowledging that the salad is the (ostensibly) better choice, but they instead gave in to their preference for the better tasting food.

      • meh says:
        January 22, 2020 at 1:01 pm

        if its a better choice, why aren’t they choosing it?

        • HowardHolmes says:
          January 22, 2020 at 1:09 pm

          Excellent comment! The person is claiming to believe something is better when they actually do not.

      • HowardHolmes says:
        January 22, 2020 at 1:05 pm

        I was thinking more in terms of “I want to lose weight but lack the willpower.” The person wants to be fat. They do not want to lose weight.

        • Matt M says:
          January 22, 2020 at 1:11 pm

          Generally agree. See also: The concept of revealed preferences, and the general sentiment of “actions speak louder than words.”

          It’s not so much that the person wants to be fat, as an end in and of itself. But it is the case that someone prefers being fat to doing the things that would be required to make themselves not fat anymore.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 1:30 pm

            They look at the package that includes getting to pig out but also includes being fat. They look at the other package of thin, but eating temperately. The have a preference for one package or the other. Their preference is shown in the window of the bathroom scale.

          • JayT says:
            January 22, 2020 at 1:48 pm

            That doesn’t explain the people that constantly yo-yo on their weight. They eat right and exercise for a few months, lose some pounds, but then fall off the wagon and go back to eating burgers and fries and watching NetFlix. Do you think that those people just have constantly shifting preferences? I would argue that their preference was always the “burgers and NetFlix” option, but they went against their preference to try and accomplish a second, contradictory, preference, which is being fit.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 1:53 pm

            JayT says “Do you think that those people just have constantly shifting preferences? I would argue that their preference was always the “burgers and NetFlix” option, but they went against their preference to try and accomplish a second, contradictory, preference, which is being fit.”

            One can only have one preference at a time, so, yes, they keep changing preferences. There is no such thing as a “second preference”. There might be a second preference but one never gets there since he also does his first preference. Claiming to have a second preference is merely claiming to be better than you are.

          • JayT says:
            January 22, 2020 at 2:03 pm

            In that case, it seems that you are just defining the word “preference” to mean “action”, and I don’t really see anything interesting to talk about there.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 3:24 pm

            JayT says:

            In that case, it seems that you are just defining the word “preference” to mean “action”, and I don’t really see anything interesting to talk about there.

            How is preference interesting without its effect on action? What is interesting about your claim to have a preference that does not translate into action? Just sounds like another word for lying.

          • Dacyn says:
            January 22, 2020 at 3:33 pm

            @HowardHolmes: I find it interesting to think about what are the contents of other people’s minds, even the parts that don’t have much effect on their actions. But of course what is interesting is a subjective question.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 3:37 pm

            Dacyn

            I find it interesting to think about what are the contents of other people’s minds, even the parts that don’t have much effect on their actions.

            You are profound as usual. I was busy making other points and typing too fast to be consistent.

          • meh says:
            January 22, 2020 at 3:40 pm

            chiming in again, since there is a lot of definition argument here.

            there is only one global perefence, but many sub preferences. sub preferences may contradict ( eat tasty food and be fit ), but the global preference in any moment, according to op, is whatever action you have decided on.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 3:51 pm

            meh says:

            there is only one global perefence, but many sub preferences.

            For the record I do not think there is any sort or kind of preference but one and there is only one of this kind. Prefer means it is that which we most want. There cannot be two of those. They cannot exist at any time other than the present. Past preferences are simply memories. Future preferences are simply imaginations (and very often incorrect). The only preference than has any significance is what we currently prefer doing.

          • meh says:
            January 22, 2020 at 4:01 pm

            you are motteing the concept now.

            how do you propose salesmen work?

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 4:06 pm

            meh says:

            you are motteing the concept now.

            how do you propose salesmen work?

            Sorry, but I don’t follow. Firstly, I don’t really follow the motte and bailey thing so try something different. I was a salesman so I know how they work, but don’t follow the relevance here. I spent my days doing things that would raise my commissions. Pretty much that was my preferred activity throughout most days. At lunch, I preferred eating lunch. Sometimes I preferring crapping. That’s how salesmen work.

          • meh says:
            January 22, 2020 at 4:11 pm

            how would you raise your commissions?? did you somehow have a way of predicting the future preferences of your customers? were you able to imagine they had consistent preferences even in imaginary situations?
            . what was your mechanism for increasing commissions?

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 4:29 pm

            meh says:

            how would you raise your commissions?? did you somehow have a way of predicting the future preferences of your customers? were you able to imagine they had consistent preferences even in imaginary situations?
            . what was your mechanism for increasing commissions?

            Oh, I see where you are going. I raised my commissions by making phone calls, sending emails, going to visit prospects, etc. What did I think of their preferences? The same I always think. Its in my OP above. I think they do what they prefer. When I send an email, my hope is they prefer to read it at some point. I hope they prefer to respond. If they do read it, it will be their ONLY preference at that time. Good for me and my commissions. Am I missing something significant here? If so, it is your point and it is still not made.

          • meh says:
            January 22, 2020 at 4:47 pm

            you make a phone call. the customer isn’t interested… how do you ever come up with something else they might be interested in? If they only have global preferences over actual states of the world, then how in hell can you generalize their preferences to any novel situation? If the customer said ‘I want to pay lower prices’, do you tell them they are lying to themselves! Do you tell them, ‘you are currently paying $X so you want to pay $X only, I can’t make any other claim’. And then think to yourself it would be stupid to offer anything less than $X, since there obviously no reason to think they ‘want’ a price less than $X?

            Or… lets say your product is more than $X, but a better quality. Do you have a reason to think they would trade off quality for price? What reason do you have?

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 5:05 pm

            meh

            since there obviously no reason to think they ‘want’ a price less than $X?

            OK, I think this sentence is what you are getting at. You model that they want to pay X-Y even though they are currently paying X. How do I operate without this assumption? If they are currently paying X, then they want to pay X. My assumption is that they are paying X (and wanting to pay X) because this is the best price they think they can get. I also think that if I offered to sell them for X-Y then they would switch their preference to buying from me. If we disagree (you and I) it seems to be that you think of them as preferring currently to pay less in the future. I think that this preference occurs at the point where X-Y becomes a possibility for them, i.e. when I offer them this price. This seems like a fine point since I think we both understand human nature enough to know they will prefer it at that time. All I am claiming here is that it is not necessary to think of them as preferring it now. In order to do that one has to create all sorts of levels of preferences, sub and minor and major and etc. and for what purpose? What is the advantage of looking at it like you do? I find many advantages of my way of viewing it for me personally. It seems in general that a lot of conflicts disappear. I never think of myself as doing what I do not want to do, nor do I ever think I have to use willpower to do anything. I only do what I like, and I do it all the time.

          • meh says:
            January 22, 2020 at 5:16 pm

            I also think that if I offered to sell them for X-Y then they would switch their preference to buying from me.

            That is a hypothetical universe that does not exist, which in your theory we are not allowed to reason about

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 5:30 pm

            meh says

            That (the future) is a hypothetical universe that does not exist, which in your theory we are not allowed to reason about

            I did not say we could not reason about the future or attempt to predict or model it. We cannot act in the future, we cannot decide in the future, or choose, or prefer or want. All those things can only happen now. We try to prefer in the future, but when we get their, we have changed or things are not quite the same, or Y has more appeal than we thought it would. We can only imagine what we might prefer, but we cannot prefer anything. It is similar to deciding. If I just ate three pieces of pie for dessert, I might DECIDE to skip dinner. How often does that happen? More often than not, dinner is not skipped because the me that is in pain from the third piece of pie is not the same as the me with the stretched stomach 4 hours from now.
            I will agree that I do use prefer a bit different that it is sometimes used. I am attempting to make the case for using the words this way.

          • meh says:
            January 22, 2020 at 5:39 pm

            I think we both understand human nature enough to know they will prefer it at that time

            So you say ‘human nautre’, but everyone else says ‘preferences’… you even later say ‘they will *prefer* it’…

            we are saying the *same* thing, but you are insisting i use your definitions of words. I say, make your point without special definitions and it will be easier to accept and understand.

          • meh says:
            January 22, 2020 at 5:46 pm

            I did not say we could not reason about the future or attempt to predict or model it.

            So please, give a word for what you call the attribute an agent has that is useful in predicting what their future preference is.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 23, 2020 at 4:46 am

            meh says:

            So please, give a word for what you call the attribute an agent has that is useful in predicting what their future preference is.

            First let me address more the problem of using prefer. If you think of yourself as always having preferences it has an effect like the following. Say you claim to prefer sitting in your recliner, reading a book and eating strawberry ice cream over going to work. You and I are at a party and you tell me this. I understand what you mean. Everything fine so far, except for the fact that you are not really in a position to choose either of those options and your claim to have a preference has what meaning exactly?

            But the real problem arises when you are, for instance, at work. You claim still have a preference for recliner, ice cream and book over being where you are. I check you leg. There is no chain attached to the chair. You are free to go home and pick up some ice cream on the way. So what does it mean to then say you have a preference for recliner, ic, and book? It means, firstly, that you are self deceived and secondly that you are suffering because are not doing what you want to do. It means you are trying to pretend that you are not the person you are, that some other force outside yourself is making you stay at work. All that is false. You are the person who wants to work, and you want to work more than you want to sit at home and eat ice cream.

            My word is that preference only has meaning when you can make a choice and that choice reflects the preference. Otherwise, it is just a speculation or a deception.

          • meh says:
            January 23, 2020 at 6:52 am

            your claim to have a preference has what meaning exactly?

            It means if it is Saturday, or if I call in ‘sick’, you know where to find me. I think you missed the question?

            So please, give a word for what you call the attribute an agent has that is useful in predicting what their future preference is.

            This is using your definition where preference=action.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 23, 2020 at 9:28 am

            meh

            So please, give a word for what you call the attribute an agent has that is useful in predicting what their future preference is.

            History

        • Lurker says:
          January 22, 2020 at 1:14 pm

          nope. I recently gained some weight for complicated reasons that aren’t actually relevant here.

          I absolutely want to loose those extra kilos, however, I also want to eat delicious food and to sit around reading all day. those desires are not compatible and the “weight loss desire” is less immediate than the others and thus often looses out. this does not mean that I actually want to be fat, this means that being fat is an unwanted side effect of the things I want and what I also want is to reverse this side effect, unfortunately those are counter to each other, so something always has to give.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 1:24 pm

            You claim to want to perform two contradictory actions which is not possible. You cannot have two wants at the same time. You want to be fat. Anyone can tell by looking.

            The claim of wanting to lose weight is just to make yourself look better than you and to avoid responsibility for wanting to be fat.

          • Lurker says:
            January 22, 2020 at 1:35 pm

            how do you conclude I want to be fat from that???
            I would get it if you said you concluded that I want to eat high caloric food or I don’t want to do sports but wanting to be fat? it’s genuinely a side effect of stuff I like.
            what about people who get fat because of medical side effects?

            (also, how do you define wanting something? maybe we’re working with different definitions here?)

          • meh says:
            January 22, 2020 at 1:42 pm

            i think this may degenrate into deifnitions and imprecise language usage of words like ‘want’ and ‘preference’

            taking all trade offs into account, the person makes a choice that will lead to weight gain. but i dont think this implies there is a core level0 preference for weight gain. if a new choice was introduced that keeps all other aspects the same but does not lead to weight gain, the person would likely choose that (like maybe someone invents artificial sweetner that is indistinguishable). the initial preference for weight gain was only in relation to trade offs of other preferences

          • Lurker says:
            January 22, 2020 at 1:48 pm

            @meh
            that actually makes a lot more sense to me than HowardHolmes’ “you want to be fat”, thanks.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 1:50 pm

            Lurker said “how do you conclude I want to be fat from that???”

            One has to take responsibility for the side effects as well as other effects of their actions. If you could, let’s say, get $100 if you push button A which also kills a person. Killing is a “side effect” of your preference to push A but none the less you “want” to kill the guy because that is part of the package you chose. No one is going to obsolve you of the side effect of killing just because you only did it for the $100. Same with eating. You want to keep eating but also want to claim “I’m better than that.” You aren’t.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 1:57 pm

            meh says “if a new choice was introduced that keeps all other aspects the same but does not lead to weight gain, the person would likely choose that ”

            If we lived in a different universe we might might not be having this discussion. But for now it is irrelevant “what a person might do if….” They only do what they do because they prefer doing it. They try but get zero real credit for claiming that they are good enough to do something else. They are not.

          • meh says:
            January 22, 2020 at 2:07 pm

            i do see your point, but you are trying to shove too much into your theory, and the use of ‘want’ will have slightly different meanings in different contexts

          • Lurker says:
            January 22, 2020 at 2:08 pm

            there’s a difference between taking responsibility for the side effects of an action and wanting that side effect.
            if there was an option A for the action without the side effect and an option B for the action with a side effect and a person would choose A instead of B if A is available then the person in question doesn’t want the side effect.
            If A is not available and thus the person chooses B, they are of course responsible for the side effect. this does not mean they actually want the side effect.
            [example: there is a medication someone needs to take and without it they will die. taking it will make them incredibly ugly. they know this. they take the medication because they want to live. this does not mean that they want to be ugly, they just want to live more than they want to be pretty]

            as far as this goes:
            “You want to keep eating but also want to claim “I’m better than that.” You aren’t.”
            this is a pretty extreme case of people hearing different things in the same statement. if you were to say “I want to loose weight, but I keep eating the wrong stuff and not exercising enough even though I theoretically know what to do” I don’t hear “I’m actually better than this”, I hear “I’m admitting I’m too weak to prioritize a long term goal over a short term goal” (this is also really common in finance)

            [also, because this “you are fat” is starting to make me really uncomfortable: I gained a couple of kilos recently because of a change in medication but I’m still within a normal range of BMI and clothing size and have made the appropriate changes to get back to normal. making those changes is not easy however and I genuinely would like a solution where I didn’t need so much discipline to get there.
            also, apparently a complete stranger calling me fat on the internet actually makes me really twitchy. I’m going to go think about that]

          • meh says:
            January 22, 2020 at 2:18 pm

            lets say i walk into a real estate agents office and say ‘i WANT a large apartment, and I WANT a cheap apartment’. the agent looks at the inventory and shows me one expensive but large apartment, and one cheap but small apartment. I wind up taking the cheap and small apartment. your theory says I want a small apartment. nobody will disagree that my preference weightings caused me to want the particular apartment that is small. there is full agreement there. but the way the word is often used, nobody is going to say i want a small apartment.

            i think you should adjust your language around the word want a bit, it will make it easier to make your other points

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 3:01 pm

            Lurker says:

            If A is not available and thus the person chooses B, they are of course responsible for the side effect. this does not mean they actually want the side effect.

            What does ‘actually wanting it” mean? They know about B and they choose B. Their actions are the same whether they “actually want it” or not. They are just fooling themselves and trying to fool others. “I do X, but it is not my fault because I did not want to do it.”

            Also one cannot want what is impossible to obtain. One cannot want to do an action one cannot do. There is no possibility of A without B so you do not want A without B. You only claim this because you want to claim that “if the universe was different I would be a better person.”

            “You want to keep eating but also want to claim “I’m better than that.” You aren’t.”
            this is a pretty extreme case of people hearing different things in the same statement. if you were to say “I want to loose weight, but I keep eating the wrong stuff and not exercising enough even though I theoretically know what to do” I don’t hear “I’m actually better than this”, I hear “I’m admitting I’m too weak to prioritize a long term goal over a short term goal” (this is also really common in finance

            Yes, but you are not addressing the fact that you are claiming to “want” something you do. Why make the claim if not to brag? Everyone would be thin if it was cost free. Why do you have to tell us you would? Answer: because you want some credit for wanting correctly. “I fail at doing, but give me credit for wanting to do.” There is no such thing. We do what we want to do. There are no long term goals. You cannot act tomorrow. You can only act now, and that action is the action you want. Claiming to do something in the future is only empty bragging.

            I genuinely would like a solution where I didn’t need so much discipline to get there.

            What is difficult (impossible) is to discipline yourself to do what you don’t want to do. What will make losing weight easy is changing your preferences. Stop wanting to be fat. If you wanted to eat temperately, you would do so easily with no discipline required. But you cannot change your preferences until you know what they are.

            also, apparently a complete stranger calling me fat on the internet actually makes me really twitchy. I’m going to go think about that]

            I don’t know you and you are using an assumed name. I am not calling YOU fat. I am agreeing with your description of yourself. If you are not fat, you are not fat. I’ll take your word for it. I am only saying that if you are fat it is because you want to be.

          • Lurker says:
            January 22, 2020 at 3:22 pm

            @HowardHolmes

            I think the way you define “wanting something” differs drastically from the meaning the word has to me. could be that’s because English is my second language or it could also be that you’re trying to shove too much meaning into an already established word.
            looking through the thread, it seems I’m not the only one who struggles with your definition. You might get a better resonance for your theory if you phrased it differently/picked different vocabulary.

            Edit: also, thank you for clarifying the fat bit. I intellectually know that you can’t possibly know enough about me to actually judge but I’m not always rational 🙂
            also: (using your way of phrasing) how does one change ones preferences?/how does someone stop wanting to be fat?

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 3:27 pm

            meh says

            i do see your point, but you are trying to shove too much into your theory, and the use of ‘want’ will have slightly different meanings in different contexts

            Care to be specific? How does my theory go too far? Define want in such a way that my theory is incorrect.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 3:35 pm

            meh says:

            nobody will disagree that my preference weightings caused me to want the particular apartment that is small. there is full agreement there. but the way the word is often used, nobody is going to say i want a small apartment.

            Maybe no one will say that, but my point is that they would be more accurate if they did. Every action has effects, some known and some unknown, some good and some bad (if you believe in good and bad..which I do not). When we analyse a possible course of action we generally consider all known effects and then net them together. It is the NET effect that becomes our preference is translates into action. So only what we want in NET has any significance for our lives. The rest is just posturing or signalling.

            i think you should adjust your language around the word want a bit, it will make it easier to make your other points

            I sort of agree but one of my points is that we never never do anything we do not want to do. This truth can have a profound effect on one’s life.

          • Dacyn says:
            January 22, 2020 at 3:39 pm

            @Lurker:

            could be that’s because English is my second language

            For the record, no it’s not, you are using the word in the normal way. HowardHolmes just likes to do a bit of semantic displacement, it is kind of his thing here.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 3:45 pm

            Lurker says:

            how does one change ones preferences?/how does someone stop wanting to be fat?

            I am 71. I “fought” overweight for most of my adult life. At age 59, I suddenly realized my problem was that I preferred the package including fat vs, the other package including thin (that package with exercise and temperance). I examined both carefully and decided that package two was definitely more appealing. As I understood it, package two meant never overeating, so I just told myself “I prefer to be thin” every time I faced an overeating decision. For some reason that worked for me and I am going on 13 years at my recommended weight. It has not been difficult, but I do need to consciously and explicitly face my preferences and admit them. I really think that our struggles are caused by self deception. I did not want to give up overeating. I had to realize this first. You have not yet been honest enough to tell yourself you do not want to give up overeating—-this means giving up forever, not just till you lose X number of pounds.

          • meh says:
            January 22, 2020 at 3:45 pm

            Maybe no one will say that, but my point is that they would be more accurate if they did

            my point is that you would be more accurate if you said that was your point. make it explicit what you mean by want, that it is different from common usage, and why it is more accurate

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 4:00 pm

            meh says:

            my point is that you would be more accurate if you said that was your point. make it explicit what you mean by want, that it is different from common usage, and why it is more accurate

            I mean by want is that which we desire or prefer, that which we find to be the thing that is best for us. I do not see where my usage differs from yours and would appreciate you attempt at further explanation. I do not include in my definition same concept like wishing which requires a different universe. To me we wish for impossible things, but only want what is possible. Maybe in that sense I differ from others who think they can want something impossible. Someone might claim to want to live to be 500 years. Given what we know, this will not happen. I consider this a wish and do not include it in a preference. People might have a preference by currently exercising which might lead to a longer life. I say they can want to exercise, or they can want to do things which lead to a longer life, but they cannot want to live to be 500. I realize people talk that way, but people say a lot of meaningless things. If someone tells me they want to live to be 500, I am wondering more why they would say such a thing rather than is this something they want.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 4:10 pm

            Dacyn says:

            HowardHolmes just likes to do a bit of semantic displacement, it is kind of his thing here.

            OK, you have my attention. I know you can do a better job of explaining than that.

          • Dacyn says:
            January 22, 2020 at 5:11 pm

            @HowardHolmes: Here is what I see. You have a concept, and others have a concept. You both compete over the same set of words like “want”, “prefer”, “desire”, and so on. I can see some possible motives for you to compete like this; you seem to think that the other concept is incoherent, and also that most of the time people use it, you and/or they would prefer if they used your concept instead.

            However, the other concept is the one that is standard in English. Since Lurker said they were not a native speaker, I clarified which was standard in English in order to make sure they were aware.

          • Lurker says:
            January 23, 2020 at 6:20 am

            @Dacyn
            thank you for the clarification, I appreciate it.

    • Lodore says:
      January 22, 2020 at 12:49 pm

      This statement

      Claiming to prefer doing other than you are doing is an attempt to avoid taking responsibility for your actions

      and this statement

      At any time there is only one thing you prefer doing, and you do it

      are inconsistent.

      If you only do what you prefer doing, then you cannot do other than your preferences mandate you to do. Responsibility has no meaning in this scenario. It doesn’t change any legal infrastructure, as it becomes about changing the preferences of future actors (‘I don’t want to to prison so I won’t do X’). But any notion of culpability vanishes.

      • Dacyn says:
        January 22, 2020 at 12:54 pm

        The first statement is inconsistent with everybody knowing the second statement, but not with the second statement itself.

      • HowardHolmes says:
        January 22, 2020 at 1:00 pm

        If one believes the second statement they would not make the claim in the first. There is no contradiction if one does not believe the second statement.

    • Dacyn says:
      January 22, 2020 at 12:50 pm

      If by “you” you mean this, I buy it.

    • Enkidum says:
      January 22, 2020 at 2:28 pm

      At any time there is only one thing you prefer doing

      What evidence do you have for this claim? It seems to go against many theories that I’ve encountered, e.g. models where different possible actions are constantly competing for neural representational space, and the one that wins out in motor cortex for long enough is the one that gets implemented. However this can fluctuate wildly over the course of a few seconds, possibly even milliseconds, making it really very difficult to talk about the “one preference” for action you currently have.

      • HowardHolmes says:
        January 22, 2020 at 3:20 pm

        Enkidum

        However this can fluctuate wildly over the course of a few seconds, possibly even milliseconds, making it really very difficult to talk about the “one preference” for action you currently have.

        You want what you want NOW. 2 milliseconds ago is what you wanted then, not now. You can only act NOW (whenever that is in brain science, you do what you want at that time). What is my proof? The opposite (we do what we do not want to do) is nonsensical.

        • Enkidum says:
          January 22, 2020 at 8:46 pm

          I guess that makes sense. But I can’t help but feel that it misses the point somewhat? I think I’ve said something very close to this to you before, but let me try again:

          Let’s say there’s some bit B of my cognitive economy that “wants” X, and some bit A that “wants” Y. And right now, at this very millisecond, A has more control over my muscles than B. So Y happens.

          But suppose the bits of this economy that usually control my speech have access to B, and no direct access to A. So if you ask me, I would tell you that I’m unaware of wanting to do Y. I just seem to do it.

          I’m not wrong that I, where “I” means something like “the bit of me that is speaking”, does not actually want to do Y. And that’s the sense in which I think you’re mistaken to say that

          The opposite (we do what we do not want to do) is nonsensical.

          You are correct, though, that it’s wrong to say that I do the things I don’t want to do, where “I” means something like “the sum totality of my cognitive economy / the whole organism that is me”, and “want” means something like “the currently dominant drive in me”. But… this is I think rather far removed from what most people mean, most of the time?

          Caveat: I could be wrong about all the above – when I started talking about neuroscience I didn’t mean to imply I had some sort of special knowledge about the neuroscience of internal drives, I really don’t know much about it at all.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 23, 2020 at 4:55 am

            Enkidum,

            I think you are saying that it makes sense to say “a part of me wants X” which is similar to saying “if things were different I would want X”. These statements might say something about us but not as much as we typically assume. It is rather irrelevant (at best) if you try to claim that you are the type of person who would really does X but some other force, or devil or whatever makes you do Y but it is not your fault. To say “a part of me would do X” is to say I am a better person that what is shown by my actions. Of course, we have incentive to tell this lie.

          • meh says:
            January 23, 2020 at 6:57 am

            But it also says, given a novel situation, here is part of the function my brain will use to calculate preference.

            The novel situations may not exist yet, but the state of my brain does exist. And my brain is great at responding to novel situations, because it is great at generalizing.

    • The Pachyderminator says:
      January 22, 2020 at 2:40 pm

      At any time there is only one thing you prefer doing, and you do it.

      If someone said to me, “You are a P-zombie, with no consciousness or internal experience whatsoever,” I would know this was false. I wouldn’t need an argument to convince myself, I would just know it. I know that your statent is false in the same way. I have a conflicted set of contradictory preferences and I’m often subject to weakness of will. That’s obvious to me and could not be otherwise.

      • HowardHolmes says:
        January 22, 2020 at 4:13 pm

        Just one example from that conflicted set of preferences might help me reply. Give me an example of a time you preferred more than one thing. Give me an example of two preferences you have which contradict.

    • bzium says:
      January 22, 2020 at 2:43 pm

      The theory that there are individuals with preferences is a very good approximation for many kinds of situations but it breaks down when you attempt to use it to model the internal structure of human decision making.

      There is no “you” and there is no “prefer”. There’s a bunch of processes running in parallel and generating conflicting plans of action, of which one gets selected in some kind of complex feedback process that nobody really understands.

      • HowardHolmes says:
        January 22, 2020 at 4:17 pm

        I certainly agree there is no you (and also no me). I agree that preferring is just a way we talk. However, if we are going to talk about we may as well try to eliminate all the contradictory language we can. It makes no sense to say I’m doing X, but do not want to do X. It makes no sense to say I am not doing what I prefer. It does make sense to say I am doing what I prefer and I want to do whatever it is that I do….at least sense on some level.

    • Kindly says:
      January 22, 2020 at 4:16 pm

      My take: claiming to lack willpower is claiming that the thing I did yesterday is (consistently) not what I now wish I’d have done.

      To the extent that you can change your own preferences, you might want to self-modify so that you prefer to do (and do) things that you’ll prefer to have done later.

      This also internally feels like doing something you don’t prefer to do, even if that’s nonsense. (Maybe my decision-making algorithm looks a bit like “do the action that gets the most points”, and doing the “willpower-y” thing gets 100 points while the other thing gets 99 points, and this is what it feels like to have those numbers be close.)

      • HowardHolmes says:
        January 22, 2020 at 4:24 pm

        This also internally feels like doing something you don’t prefer to do, even if that’s nonsense.

        My take is that it feels that way because we allow this sort of thinking. I find that if I remind myself that I AM doing what I prefer, the feeling goes away. I often ask myself what it is that I would prefer doing if not what I am doing. My answer assumes my belief that we can only prefer that which is possible. So if something comes to my consciousness to answer that question, I review my decision and decide which I prefer, and do that. I also know in advance that I WILL decide to do that which prefer. If I still feel like I don’t prefer my current action, I tell myself to stop being silly.

        • meh says:
          January 22, 2020 at 4:49 pm

          I often ask myself what it is that I would prefer doing if not what I am doing.

          I don’t understand how this question can even make sense to you?

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 22, 2020 at 5:10 pm

            meh says:

            “I often ask myself what it is that I would prefer doing if not what I am doing.”

            I don’t understand how this question can even make sense to you?

            It is a rhetorical question. It is a reminder that I am indeed doing what I prefer doing. I do the same things you do; for me, they are always my preferred activity. It does make a difference. I have tried it the other way. I think all people are just like me. They always do exactly as they want. They just do not realize it and are therefore missing some low hanging fruit in the form of satisfaction and peace of mind.

          • meh says:
            January 22, 2020 at 5:42 pm

            It’s only a rhetorical question that makes sense if you sometimes allow yourself to use language as everyone else does.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 23, 2020 at 5:15 am

            meh says:

            It’s only a rhetorical question that makes sense if you sometimes allow yourself to use language as everyone else does.

            In my opinion language evolved primarily to allow for deception of self and others. If I used language as other do it would only serve to promote the deception that is ubiquitous in the world.

          • meh says:
            January 23, 2020 at 7:00 am

            Deception is what is happening. A non-native speaker got utterly confused up-thread.

          • Dacyn says:
            January 23, 2020 at 11:50 am

            @HowardHolmes: I agree with u/meh’s comment here. The fact that you still ask yourself this rhetorical question is a sign that you still retain something of the old (which you call deceptive) definition. I think it is interesting to ask what is it that is retained. In my opinion it is nothing more than positive valence: the word “prefer” standardly comes with an attached positive valence for “I am doing what I prefer/want to be doing”. So that is why asking yourself this rhetorical question gives you satisfaction.

            If you did not carry any meaning or valence from the old definition, your statement would be just a tautology, and it is not clear why you would say a tautology.

            Maybe I will ask a rhetorical question: does assigning positive valence to “I am doing what I want to be doing” constitute “deception”? It is rhetorical because the answer depends on whether and how you extend the concept of “deception” to deal with valence.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 23, 2020 at 12:53 pm

            Meh and dacyn

            Re: my rhetorical questioning. The way it appears to me is that I am tempted to abdicate responsibility for my actions. Maybe that is from habit, or nature or something else. It seems easy to blame someone (thing) other than myself. I hold to the belief that this is not truthful. I hold to the belief that “whatever happens to me is my fault (or I give permission for)(no exception). But, like I said sometimes I am tempted to miss this point (though less and less as time passes). Asking myself why I am doing X or “whose decision is it do X?” or “am I doing what I want to do?” is making explicit my beliefs. Do I need to do this while eating a pizza? I do not recall that ever being necessary. It seems to be more functional when I am cleaning the toilets or something. If I am not enjoying cleaning the toilet as much as eating pizza I attribute it to incorrect thinking. If you are accusing me of occasionally thinking incorrectly, I can only say “yes, but when it happens, it is my fault”. I believe that thinking correctly on these matters is possible can become rather automatic. My guess is that we are trained to not take responsibility, and that we can untrain.

            I’m probably missing your point, but try again.

          • Dacyn says:
            January 23, 2020 at 2:02 pm

            @HowardHolmes:

            It seems easy to blame someone (thing) other than myself. I hold to the belief that this is not truthful.

            What is the difference between “blaming” someone other than yourself and pointing out a series of causal links between them and the result? It seems to me the only difference is again, affect or valence. But I don’t see how valence can be truthful or not truthful.

            If I am not enjoying cleaning the toilet as much as eating pizza I attribute it to incorrect thinking.

            So, what I am missing here is the connection between believing that you are “doing what you want to do”, and enjoying cleaning the toilet. I claimed that it was a holdover from the standard English connotations of “want”; you don’t seem to have given me an alternate explanation.

    • Thegnskald says:
      January 22, 2020 at 6:00 pm

      This is either nerd-sniping, or confusion. I’ll assume it is confusion.

      You are treating the word preference as it is used when, for example, selecting a jar of peanut butter. Selecting one thing that is better than other things.

      What you omit is that context is part of the preference. I’d prefer not to fill out my tax paperwork, if that was the end of it; however, I prefer to fill out tax paperwork now, rather than deal with what would happen if I don’t. So in the jar-of-peanut-butter sense, I prefer doing my tax paperwork when I do my tax paperwork. However, that is my preference only in reference to the context.

      I don’t prefer to hand a random person my wallet. If they have a gun pointed at me, I might prefer to do so.

      When people express a preference for something other than what they are doing, what they are doing is complaining about the context in which they are doing what they are doing; in general, whatever problems not doing what they are doing would entail. So their expression of preference is often not a statement about what they are doing, but a statement about what they would experience if they weren’t doing it.

      Thus, enter willpower. When somebody says they don’t have enough willpower, what they mean is that they want to experience less (or experience less keenly, or with more perspective that makes it less significant, or something along these lines – willpower is a somewhat vague reference, and different people have different ideas of what it means) whatever it is they would experience, if they weren’t doing what they are doing.

      • HowardHolmes says:
        January 23, 2020 at 5:05 am

        Thegnskald says:

        What you omit is that context is part of the preference. ….
        I don’t prefer to hand a random person my wallet. If they have a gun pointed at me, I might prefer to do so.

        So you are claiming to have something called a preference that is not specific to a context. This is not true. If you claim “I do not prefer handing my wallet to a random person” you are including context such as “assuming the random person does not have a gun on me” “or assuming the random person is not a person in authority over me” etc. Preferences always have context.

        My point is that when try to use preference without context we end up deceiving ourselves and others. “I am working but I would rather be playing” Our context is “…if it was possible to get paid for playing.” It is not possible. We are merely complaining, as you say, and trying to make ourselves into something we are not. The fact is that we ARE the type of person who prefers work to play when it comes to deciding how to allocate our time.

        • Thegnskald says:
          January 23, 2020 at 9:25 am

          It is hard to respond charitably when your response amounts to “No, my understanding of the way this word is used is 100% factual and any usage that doesn’t comply with my understanding is deceptive.”

          Bluntly, if you find the way everyone else uses a word to be misleading, the problem is with how you have internally mapped the word to concepts, not everyone else.

    • NostalgiaForInfinity says:
      January 23, 2020 at 2:34 am

      “Claiming to prefer doing other than you are doing is an attempt to avoid taking responsibility for your actions.”

      Your statements leave no opportunity for anyone to take responsibility for their actions because under your description, people don’t seem to have free will: everyone does what they prefer to do at any given time.

      (Unless they can change their preferences – but at any given time someone’s preference can be not to change their preferences and people remain slaves to their preferences).

      • HowardHolmes says:
        January 23, 2020 at 5:09 am

        You seem to be suggesting a person would freely choose to do X when he prefers doing Y. Please make up an example of this happening so I can try to get my mind around it. You seem to be saying it would be coherent to say to the Baskin Robbins guy “I prefer the strawberry, but give me the chocolate marshmellow.” The BR guy will think “he needs no nuts because he already is one.”

        • EchoChaos says:
          January 23, 2020 at 5:14 am

          Sure. I strongly prefer lying around and playing video games. I don’t like working out.

          But I head out to the garage every day to move iron because I have chosen to.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 23, 2020 at 5:17 am

            Echochoas

            Sure. I strongly prefer lying around and playing video games. I don’t like working out.

            But I head out to the garage every day to move iron because I have chosen to.

            No problem except this statement is totally incoherent. Why, then, do you workout?

          • EchoChaos says:
            January 23, 2020 at 5:20 am

            @HowardHolmes

            Because I have chosen to work out instead of playing video games, which would be my preference.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 23, 2020 at 5:35 am

            Echochaos

            So your reason for choosing to work out is that you choose to work out.

            Coherent but meaningless.

          • EchoChaos says:
            January 23, 2020 at 5:45 am

            @HowardHolmes

            You asked for an example, I gave one.

            I am not sure why you’re dismissing it as meaningless, given that it is exactly an example of what you asked for. If you were going to dismiss any such example, why ask for one?

          • Nick says:
            January 23, 2020 at 5:49 am

            Epistemic status: conciliatory

            It would help if you could explain how you’re making your decision if you’re not basing it on preferences. That might help Howard to see how there is more going on than “having a preference for doing one thing” -> “doing that thing”.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 23, 2020 at 5:51 am

            Echochaos

            If you do not wish to address why you choose to work out given you do not prefer working out then I would assume it is your preference to not address it. “Because I choose to” is not a reason in any form or fashion.

          • EchoChaos says:
            January 23, 2020 at 5:52 am

            @Nick

            That’s my point. I am doing something against preferences because I have decided to.

            The feedback in the short and medium term is pretty much all negative. I get DOMS, I miss out on prime Slay the Spire time, the actual workout feels bad, but I choose intellectually to override all those preferences and work out anyway.

            @HowardHolmes

            You are just taking as an axiom that “everything is a preference”. Your statement as you are arguing it is unfalsifiable and therefore uninteresting.

          • Nick says:
            January 23, 2020 at 6:14 am

            @EchoChaos
            I’m not usually one to agree with Howard here, but it looks to me like you’re throwing yourself on the other horn of the dilemma: isn’t your action therefore completely irrational?

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 23, 2020 at 6:15 am

            Echo

            I find it interesting that you want to take credit for all the good effects of your choices but wish to deny responsibility for all the bad effects. If one believes in good/bad then one understands that most actions entail a bit of both. Our ultimate choice depends on how we assess the NET effect. You portray yourself as too good to be preferring anything but good and blaming some force outside yourself for everything bad.

          • EchoChaos says:
            January 23, 2020 at 6:36 am

            @Nick

            I am indeed saying that. My actions are not based on rationality, but on choice. I don’t choose rationally. In fact, I often choose irrationally and rationalize it to myself later.

            @HowardHolmes

            Working out is an example of a choice that I make that is good. There are just as often choices I make that are bad. I’m no saint, nor have I claimed to be.

            For example, I prefer not to cause emotional harm to my wife. She’s a wonderful woman and it makes me feel bad when I do. But sometimes I do indeed choose to do things that hurt her.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 23, 2020 at 6:50 am

            Echo

            For example, I prefer not to cause emotional harm to my wife. She’s a wonderful woman and it makes me feel bad when I do. But sometimes I do indeed choose to do things that hurt her.

            IMO you are clearly trying to take credit for being better than your choices. Who is it that is choosing to hurt your wife if not you?

            “Oh, it can’t be me because I prefer not to.” Who are you blaming?

          • EchoChaos says:
            January 23, 2020 at 6:56 am

            @HowardHolmes

            Not sure how you got that out. What I am saying is that “me” is composed of two layers of mental action.

            The first is the underlying preference layer. This is the part that “prefers” to play video games, lie around, take care of my wife, etc. Some of those preferences are good and I try to reinforce them. When I’m “not thinking about what I’m doing”, this is the layer that performs actions by default.

            The second is the controllable layer, the “conscious mind”. I don’t want to say rational mind, because it’s just as often irrational. But it can override the preference layer, both for good and for ill.

            For good, it can override to work out when I want to be lazy. For ill, it can override and be mean to my wife when I want to be nice.

            But any action emerging from either layer is “me” and I am solely responsible for it.

          • meh says:
            January 23, 2020 at 7:09 am

            @EchoChaos

            This is where HH argument has some sense, he is just using words in ways that make it hard to understand.

            Your global preference over the entire state of the world is to spend some time everyday working out. If you preferred not to exercise, then you wouldn’t exercise. So yes on a low level you prefer spending your time playing video games, but on a global level you prefer putting some of that time towards exercise, (because you prefer the benefits of said exercise).

            HH uses the ‘global’ preference only, and does not allow people to express sub-preferences.

          • EchoChaos says:
            January 23, 2020 at 7:23 am

            @meh

            And what I am saying is that the use of “preference” in that way is nonsensical, because it becomes a tautology.

            “You do X because you prefer X.” “How do you know I prefer X?” “Because you only do what you prefer and you did X.”

            Preference in language is only meaningful if it is something that you lean towards but can override.

          • Nick says:
            January 23, 2020 at 7:47 am

            @EchoChaos

            Working out is an example of a choice that I make that is good. There are just as often choices I make that are bad. I’m no saint, nor have I claimed to be.

            Okay, but based on what you said above, I don’t think it makes sense to say you made a good choice. Sure, exercise is good for you, but by your own admission you didn’t choose it because it’s good for you. You might as well have flipped a coin to decide what to do.

          • meh says:
            January 23, 2020 at 7:50 am

            And what I am saying is that the use of “preference” in that way is nonsensical, because it becomes a tautology.

            I agree it becomes nonsensical if you aren’t clear in what you are saying or how you are using the word.

            OP is saying, given total states of the world, you have a preference for one or the other. I’m with him here, but I would say this preference is calculated from sub-preferences that generalize to the global state. OP wants to ignore that any such sub-preferences exists/are meaningful/make sense.

            Now, it sounds like your position is that *only* base level sub-preferences exist, and any global preference is instead a ‘choice’.

            ….we’re really just arguing definition I believe.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 23, 2020 at 9:41 am

            Echo

            Which part, again, is the part that wants to hurt your wife? Are you saying neither part wants to hurt her? Is she being hurt by a third part?

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 23, 2020 at 9:43 am

            meh

            Preference in language is only meaningful if it is something that you lean towards but can override.

            Who is doing the overriding, and why?

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 23, 2020 at 9:49 am

            meh

            HH uses the ‘global’ preference only, and does not allow people to express sub-preferences.

            As I understand it then you and I agree about global preference if I will use your word. Since only global preference affects action, tell me again why I need sub preferences? My thought would be “just to brag.”

          • Dacyn says:
            January 23, 2020 at 12:14 pm

            @All: I agree with HowardHolmes about EchoChaos’s example, but only because it’s an example where the action you actually did was the one that took more thought. If you choose to work out you’ve clearly make some kind of calculation that the benefits of doing so outweigh the costs. That may disagree with your intuitive comparison but it’s still normal English to call it a “preference”.

            The more difficult scenario is one where you take the action that is based on less thought, e.g. going for a donut instead of working out. My understanding is that standard English says that this is not “your preference”, at least if “you” is interpreted holistically, because if you average out what you would have chosen yourself to do if you had had the option over time, you would usually have preferred to make yourself work out. I think this definition is not nonsensical, because we can imagine a counterfactual where you can push a button to force an alternate version of yourself to do something.

            Of course, establishing what the standard English definitions of words are doesn’t fully address HowardHolmes’s point, which seems to be more about how people use them to appeal to others’ emotions (i.e. making other people “not blame them” for things) in a non-veridical manner (although HowardHolmes hasn’t yet explained what it would mean for an emotion to be non-veridical)

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 23, 2020 at 1:05 pm

            dacyn

            My understanding is that standard English says that this is not “your preference”, at least if “you” is interpreted holistically, because if you average out what you would have chosen yourself to do if you had had the option over time, you would usually have preferred to make yourself work out. I think this definition is not nonsensical, because we can imagine a counterfactual where you can push a button to force an alternate version of yourself to do something.

            So at the time he goes for donuts he really prefers working out? That’s as nonsensical as any other. If he did not prefer going for donuts who was it holding a gun to his head to make him go? Yes, you can assert that on the last 7 days in a row he preferred working out, but while this might give you some ability to predict his day 8 behavior, you would be mistaken in your prediction if he went for donuts.

            Explain further about this button and what it does.

          • Dacyn says:
            January 23, 2020 at 1:25 pm

            @HowardHolmes:

            So at the time he goes for donuts he really prefers working out?

            No, I didn’t say that. I said that he (not at any specific point in time) would “prefer” it if he went to work out at that particular point in time. But usually when he talks to others about his action, it will not be at the same point when the action was made, so it seems reasonable to bring various time-slices into the discussion.

            Explain further about this button and what it does.

            I mean, it is kind of tricky to specify exactly because the only way for the button him to actually decide what the dilemma him will do would be mind control or some kind of force. But there are plausibly things that are likely to sway the dilemma him one way or the other, and absent other considerations it seems plausible that button him would act in ways that tend to encourage working out. (I don’t know if this is what you were looking for, maybe you wanted a different kind of specificity)

            Anyway, another example could be someone getting angry, they know if they lose their temper, they will get punished, but they lose their temper anyway. I think this is somewhat analogous to reflex reactions (i.e. flinching) — the gap between stimulus and response may be so short that conscious thought may not have the opportunity to do anything. In standard English I think we would say that neither of these are preferred outcomes (well the reflex one may be incidentally preferred, that’s not the point) but I guess you would say that losing your temper is preferred, I don’t know what you would say about the reflex reaction.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 23, 2020 at 1:51 pm

            Dacyn says:

            In standard English I think we would say that neither of these are preferred outcomes (well the reflex one may be incidentally preferred, that’s not the point) but I guess you would say that losing your temper is preferred, I don’t know what you would say about the reflex reaction.

            First let me address you statement about “standard english”. I am getting thrown under the bus due to non-standard use of terms. This is not the case. When you claim that people say something in “standard english” I am not saying that they do not say that. I am saying that what they say is incorrect. Just because everyone says something does not make it correct.

            Both losing temper and reflex actions are the preferred actions. I am not trying to make any points about how action originates or even about the existence of preferences. May there is no such thing as mental states. My points strictly refer to the nonsensical way we think and talk about these things.

          • Dacyn says:
            January 23, 2020 at 2:11 pm

            @HowardHolmes:

            Just because everyone says something does not make it correct.

            But with the definitions of words, it does. Words are given meaning through social consensus, so if people agree that a word means a certain thing, then that is what it in fact means.

            Both losing temper and reflex actions are the preferred actions.

            Interesting, I will remember this.

            My points strictly refer to the nonsensical way we think and talk about these things.

            I think you and others would find conversations less confusing if you concentrated on explaining why you think that the standard ways of talking are nonsensical, without trying to displace the definitions of words via repeated use of your own definitions. This can be difficult if you don’t have practice with this sort of thing, but you can always give it a try 🙂

          • EchoChaos says:
            January 24, 2020 at 4:50 am

            @Nick

            I made a good choice if the choice I made has good and desirable effects (working out mostly does). I made a bad choice if the choice has bad or sinful effects.

            Whether my base preferences are good or bad also based on their outcomes.

            I think the difference is that I am using preference for the unconscious actions that I take without thinking about it (we all do such things) and choice for the conscious overrides of those unconscious actions.

            I think this is a fairly typical use of both words. “I prefer to eat ice cream and get fat, but I went for a run instead” is a perfectly normal way to speak.

            And I want to be very clear that it is in no way only taking credit for my conscious actions nor abdicating responsibility for the unconscious. The concept of “me” encompasses both and I am responsible for both.

          • Dacyn says:
            January 24, 2020 at 9:08 am

            @EchoChaos: I suppose it is not too uncommon to call those preferences, but I think they are usually called whims or urges, or at least qualified as “transient preferences”.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 24, 2020 at 10:05 am

            Echo

            What does it mean to say you do X but prefer doing Y?

        • NostalgiaForInfinity says:
          January 23, 2020 at 6:05 am

          My point is that no-one is “freely choosing” anything, they are fulfilling their preferences. If you prefer X to Y, you do X and you could not do otherwise. So in what sense is anyone choosing to do anything?

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 23, 2020 at 6:18 am

            Oh, I see.

            You wanted to change the discussion to freewill vs determinism. I think my points are still true in any case. “We always do that which aligns with our preference” says the same as “we always do what we prefer doing.”

          • NostalgiaForInfinity says:
            January 23, 2020 at 6:28 am

            @HowardHolmes

            I didn’t want to change the discussion to free will vs determinism. My point was that “everyone acts according to their preferences” logically (I think) reduces to determinism.

            “If I prefer to do A over B, I do A” doesn’t seem to allow for any choices at any point. In what sense do I make any choices ever if I always just follow what my preferences are?

          • meh says:
            January 23, 2020 at 7:12 am

            @NostalgiaForInfinity

            Is it true that:

            “If I prefer to do A over B, I do A” is determinism,

            and

            “If I prefer to do A over B, I sometimes do A, sometimes B” is free will?

          • NostalgiaForInfinity says:
            January 23, 2020 at 7:57 am

            @meh

            “If I prefer to do A over B, I do A” is determinism

            It depends on what precisely we mean by preferences. In the sense that it’s being used here – that people do what their top preference is, and if they say they prefer to do something other than what they do, they are lying – I’d say yes.
            If people have control over their preferences, then they would be making decisions and it wouldn’t be determinism – but then you could argue they have a preference for having a different set of preferences and we’re back where we started. This is my objection to this kind of reductive use of “preferences”. It is determinism only for this use.

            “If I prefer to do A over B, I sometimes do A, sometimes B” is free will?

            I think that “If I prefer to do A over B, I sometimes do A, sometimes B” is necessary but not sufficient for free will. But this statement is impossible if you’re using the above definition of preferences.

            I also want to stress that I don’t have strong feelings on free will vs determinism, just that it seemed to me that HowardHolmes’ interpretation of preferences essentially is determinism.

      • Dacyn says:
        January 23, 2020 at 11:59 am

        under your description, people don’t seem to have free will: everyone does what they prefer to do at any given time

        I know free will is a controversial subject, but I think a standard compatibilist view is that free will means that your actions are caused by your intentions. This seems perfectly compatible with HowardHolmes’ views.

    • Enkidum says:
      January 23, 2020 at 10:35 am

      Trying another go-round here.

      Muscular activity (a.k.a doing something) is a singularity – muscles can only stretch or contract in a single way at a single moment in time.

      So you would clearly be wrong to say that you did A and not-A.

      Any physical action has some kind of mental “push” or drive to initiate it (let’s say this is true for the sake of argument, it’s probably a lot more complicated than that).

      Since only one action is done at a given time, clearly only one of these drives is successful at a given time.

      That successful drive appears to be what you are calling “preference”.

      But other people (myself included) think it is useful to talk about the ones that are not currently successful, and we have also called those “preferences”.

      If you don’t like calling currently non-dominant drives “preferences”, we can stick to “currently non-dominant drives”. But this is a rather long phrase.

      The only potential disagreement I can see here is if you deny that currently non-dominant drives exist. But I don’t think you do. In which case I think the large majority of the arguments here are purely semantic, about what level we should use the word “preference” for.

      • HowardHolmes says:
        January 23, 2020 at 1:11 pm

        dacyn

        My understanding is that standard English says that this is not “your preference”, at least if “you” is interpreted holistically, because if you average out what you would have chosen yourself to do if you had had the option over time, you would usually have preferred to make yourself work out. I think this definition is not nonsensical, because we can imagine a counterfactual where you can push a button to force an alternate version of yourself to do something.

        So at the time he goes for donuts he really prefers working out? That’s as nonsensical as any other. If he did not prefer going for donuts who was it holding a gun to his head to make him go? Yes, you can assert that on the last 7 days in a row he preferred working out, but while this might give you some ability to predict his day 8 behavior, you would be mistaken in your prediction if he went for donuts.

        Explain further about this button and what it does.

        • Enkidum says:
          January 23, 2020 at 1:14 pm

          I think you meant to post that in reply elsewhere. It gets complicated on these long threads :).

      • HowardHolmes says:
        January 23, 2020 at 1:15 pm

        Enkidum

        I think the large majority of the arguments here are purely semantic

        I think a lot of people routinely think they are doing something they do not want to do. During normal business hours many business people think they would rather be playing. This is wrongheaded and has real consequences on their lives. My point is not merely semantics although this seems to be a common approach in comments.

        • Enkidum says:
          January 23, 2020 at 1:18 pm

          OK, so I guess there is a genuine disagreement between us then.

          I do believe it is possible to want things I do not currently have, or to want to do things I am not currently doing.

          You seem to be arguing this is impossible?

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 23, 2020 at 1:29 pm

            Its impossible for several reasons. One reason is that we can only do what we prefer doing.

          • Dacyn says:
            January 23, 2020 at 1:31 pm

            @Enkidum:

            OK, so I guess there is a genuine disagreement between us then.

            Before you say this, you should be warned he also uses a nonstandard definition of “want”. (Although I actually think you’re probably right that there’s a genuine disagreement.)

          • Enkidum says:
            January 23, 2020 at 2:07 pm

            OK, bowing out of this one. I feel like I’ve gone out of my way to try to be clear, but you’re just repeating the same thing over and over again.

    • paragonal_ says:
      January 23, 2020 at 10:53 am

      HowardHolmes,

      JayT has already asked something along similar lines but you didn’t spell it out explicitly: is there a difference between actions and preferences for you? If every action corresponds to the preference at the moment and preferences which don’t lead to actions should not be called preferences, preferences and actions simply are the same thing. So just to clarify: are you arguing for this or am I missing something?

      • HowardHolmes says:
        January 23, 2020 at 1:24 pm

        paragonal_ says:

        JayT has already asked something along similar lines but you didn’t spell it out explicitly: is there a difference between actions and preferences for you? If every action corresponds to the preference at the moment and preferences which don’t lead to actions should not be called preferences, preferences and actions simply are the same thing. So just to clarify: are you arguing for this or am I missing something?

        The preference refers to an attitude toward an action, not the action itself. If you are at work you might believe “I prefer playing baseball rather than working.” The word prefer here is not the same as working or baseball. It describe a state of mind, not an action. The sentence is clearly wrongheaded and leads to unnecessary suffering.

        • paragonal_ says:
          January 23, 2020 at 2:33 pm

          If you are at work you might believe “I prefer playing baseball rather than working.” The word prefer here is not the same as working or baseball.

          Sure but the word prefer isn’t used with your intended meaning here but with the meaning you are arguing against.

          If we use your meaning, when I’m at work I should think “I prefer to work right now.”. Since I’m not playing baseball, I should think “I prefer not to play baseball right now.” How is this different from thinking “I’m working right now.” and “I’m not playing baseball right now.”? I.e. using your meaning, what does the word preference convey in addition to a mere description of the action?

    • paragonal_ says:
      January 23, 2020 at 2:55 pm

      HowardHolmes,

      your general point is well taken and I think there’s merit to at least being able to look at things from your angle. Besides the meta point which I made in the previous post, there’s also an object level point which makes me think.

      Suppose I did behave in a way which has done great harm to me in the past. Taking your viewpoint, I wanted this and preferred to act like this given the circumstances (i.e. I preferred the package including this specific harm over alternate packages). I predict that if I come into the situation again, I am going to act like this again. I.e. I am going to take the package including this specific harm again. Using your wording, how would you describe my current efforts to prevent this?

      • paragonal_ says:
        January 23, 2020 at 3:35 pm

        I’ve been thinking some more. Let me go a bit further using your wording.

        Let’s say currently, my preference is to prevent the consequences I’ve outlined in the previous post. In order to achieve this, I can for example reshape my future environment by adding costs to the undesired package or benefits to the desired package or I can reshape my future preferences directly by taking chemicals, for example.

        What I don’t like about your point of view is that both the actions which lead to the specific harm as well as my effort to reduce future harms are on equal footing. Above you wrote “I am not trying to make any points about how action originates”. But if an action has led to harm that’s the very point: how can I take a different action in the future?

        So it seems to me that I’m not fully on board with your terminology because I want to say more than you.

        • HowardHolmes says:
          January 23, 2020 at 4:10 pm

          Your explanation here did not help me. Now you seem to be talking about adding benefits to a desired package (making it more desirable??) and adding costs to an undesired package??

          You might have an interesting question here, but I am struggling with terminology. If you did something you preferred doing in the past then afterwards you should be able to assess what you thought about your decision. In other words, going in you thought the decision to do X would produce a net good (that it was preferred or desirable….surely you would not claim to prefer something you thought was a net harm! So after completing the action are you still of the opinion it was a net good? If so, I am unclear why you would not want to keep doing it over and over.
          Perhaps in retrospect you decided it was a NET harm. If so, then you do not desire or prefer doing it again. If you do not prefer doing it, you will not do it. No problem.

          My best guess is that you currently have not decided whether it is good or bad.

          • paragonal_ says:
            January 23, 2020 at 6:02 pm

            Let me make the example more tangible.

            [I’m still trying to write from your point of view exclusively. So please don’t assume hidden motives (like I only claim to prefer) but instead correct my wording if you have objections against how I describe my actions and motives.]

            Let’s assume I am morbidly obese. My doctor has told me, if I keep overeating, I will die soon.

            The last time I was hungry, I considered to restrict my eating in order to stay alive but I preferred to overeat because the food was so delicious. I predict that I am going to prefer to overeat again if get hungry again. So in situations where I am hungry and there’s an abundance of food, I prefer the package (overeat and die soon) to alternate packages like (restrict eating and live longer).

            Right now, I am not hungry and I prefer to live longer. In order to achieve this, I intend to take appetite suppressants which modify my predicted future preferences.

            It seems to me that for you, all actions are on equal footing (just preferences in the here and now). For me, actions which counteract predicted future actions of myself which are at odds with my preferences now are special.
