Especially if my current preferences are pretty constant and if they only get overridden under certain circumstances which occur during short time intervals.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 24, 2020 at 5:50 am

            Paragonal

            I do not think our view is at odds here. The only decision you face currently is to take or not take appetite suppressant. Your analysis is that the suppressant will produce healthier eating. If you are correct then your preference for them is obvious.

            Let’s say you are currently famished and a feast is spread before you. Let’s say there is also a pill there that will cause you to eat only the salad. Do you take that pill?

          • paragonal_ says:
            January 24, 2020 at 7:42 am

            I agree that there’s some common ground but I don’t know how far it goes. For me, non-constant preferences over time create tensions which you don’t seem to acknowledge.

            In the OP, you write “Claiming to lack willpower is an attempt to take credit for preferences you do not have.” I agree that something along these lines is possible (and maybe even common) but the feeling of a lack of willpower can also have a genuine origin: the realization that a genuine effort to propagate a past preference to the present situation has failed.

            If I find myself in a situation again where I prefer to overeat after an intervention like taking the pill, two interpretations are possible:
            1) maybe it has just been a hidden preference which I was deluded about all along or
            2) maybe my intervention didn’t work as predicted (maybe the pill just didn’t work, maybe I predicted my future preference to eat healthily under the new circumstances wrongly, etc.).
            Your stance seems to admit only the first interpretation while I view the second interpretation to be true at least in *some* cases.

            So I think that there’s a version of willpower and conflicting preferences and associated ideas which makes sense outside the context of denying responsibility for ones own actions: namely in regard to the question of how to best propagate current preferences into the future. For you, this seems to be a non-issue but for me, it’s an important issue which deserves its own concepts and names.

          • HowardHolmes says:
            January 24, 2020 at 10:00 am

            paragonal
            As a tangent diet pills don’t work. If they did everyone would be skinny, and some diet pill inventor would be richer than Bezos.

            Here are what you mean by “preferences over time”:

            1) I prefer being able to eat anything I want without gaining weight.

            2) I prefer being able to eat temperately without giving up the joy of pigging out.

            3) I prefer only good effects coming from my actions rather than good and bad.

            What makes these not preferences is not the timing but rather they are not options you have or will ever have and are not presented to you for a choice.

            Now let’s be more realistic and imagine there is this permanent preference within you: “I prefer to eat temperately and be thin over pigging out and being fat.”

            If you had such a preference eating temperately would take zero willpower, and you would be thin. Also note that its being permanent is irrelevant. If you had it each time you sat down to eat it would be the same effect.

            The problem is you do not have this preference permanently. You occasionally have it, but mostly not. Your true preference when you sit to eat is “I prefer the pleasure of overeating over the pleasure of being healthier, being more attractive, feeling better, moving better, having a more positive self image. If there was such a thing as willpower it would take a lot of it to overcome such a preference.

            You are not failing because of lack of willpower. In fact you are not failing at all. You are living the life you prefer. You think you have a preference like number one above and that this preference is hurting you and affecting life and causing problems. You are blaming your problems on the overeating preference (alone) and not taking responsibility that it is your choice to forego all the things like good health mentioned above. You are actually blaming your problems on the fact that the world is as it is rather than meeting your fantasies. When you start taking responsibility for the fact that YOU (Paragonal) are intentionally and purposely choosing bad health, bad feelings and unattractiveness then you will see the path to actually making a change. Then you will see that these things are within your power to have simply by choosing to prefer them, or more accurately choosing to accept responsibility for them.

          • cassander says:
            January 24, 2020 at 10:04 am

            @HowardHolmes

            As a tangent diet pills don’t work. If they did everyone would be skinny, and some diet pill inventor would be richer than Bezos.

            I might rephrase that as “they don’t work without nasty side effects.”

          • paragonal_ says:
            January 24, 2020 at 2:06 pm

            @HowardHolmes:

            Here are what you mean by “preferences over time”:
            […]
            What makes these not preferences is not the timing but rather they are not options you have or will ever have and are not presented to you for a choice.

            Please don’t make up your own scenario but point out explicitly what’s wrong with the specific preferences I have given. We agree that when I’m hungry, I prefer the package to (overeat and die sooner). You don’t seem to believe that my preference at times when I’m not hungry genuinely can be to live longer and take actions to prevent myself from overeating in the future unless these actions are 100% successful. Also you seem to see preferences as mostly static while in my experience. they fluctuate. I think we won’t reach agreement here.

            You are not failing because of lack of willpower.

            You are again not sticking to my scenario. I didn’t say that I was failing. I wrote that I have failed *to propagate past preferences into the present*. I didn’t indicate that I do things which I don’t prefer at the moment of doing them and I also didn’t try to hand over responsibility to something external of me.

            I don’t see much sense in going further here because I don’t see you really engaging with my scenario but making up your own hypothetical.

            Thanks for the exchange. I certainly have learned something and as I have written in the beginning, I see merit in your point of view. I just think it has some blind spots and doesn’t explain all the things about human behavior and motives which I’m interested in.

          • Clutzy says:
            January 24, 2020 at 4:58 pm

            @ Cassander

            I might rephrase that as “they don’t work without nasty side effects.”

            A very important addendum.

            Amphetamines work, they just are addictive and cause several heart conditions.

            2,4 dinitrophenol works, but it causes overheating and death with even small overdoses.

            Low does emetics work, but you feel horrible the whole time with various other side effects.

      • HowardHolmes says:
        January 23, 2020 at 4:00 pm

        Using your wording, how would you describe my current efforts to prevent this?

        My first thought is that it seems strange that you claim to want to prevent doing something you preferred doing the last time and anticipate you will prefer doing it again should the circumstances arise. It seems like you are not telling the straight story here because that seems contradictory. I will now read your next post and see if that clears anything up. My assumption here is that the harm cannot be separated from the total package…which total package you prefer (or claim to prefer).

    • Randy M says:
      January 22, 2020 at 11:58 am

      Thanks all. Mine mysteriously died when my daughter was watching a DVD last night. Less mysterious when I opened it up and vacuumed out the dust bunnies. It’s probably either power supply or HDD failure, I assume.
      I’ve upgraded before but not built from scratch.

      How hard is it to make sure all parts are compatible with the case & motherboard & each other? My current hand-me-down had to have a special narrow form graphics card.

      • DragonMilk says:
        January 22, 2020 at 12:37 pm

        I’m no expert, but my understanding is that the new generation (post 2016?) of motherboards is super standardized so that everything is plug and play. You should check on websites suggested above to verify, though, as they will point out any incompatibilities.

        The nice thing about cases is they’re fairly cheap ($25 if you’re willing), so that should be the least of your worries.

      • voso says:
        January 22, 2020 at 12:51 pm

        The main things you’ll have to worry about are motherboard socket and CPU compatibility (AMD CPUs are a different socket than Intel), and motherboard size and case compatibility. Things like RAM compatibility and GPU socket compatibility are largely hassle-free now with new builds, as we are well into a standard at this point (DDR4 and PCI-E, respectively), it’s only really a problem with upgrading old machines now.

      • DragonMilk says:
        January 22, 2020 at 1:30 pm

        I will say that if you care about having a legit copy of windows, don’t mind a little bloatware, and aren’t a gamer, some prebuilt machines can be very competitive in pricing.

        There’s something to be said about economies of sale and OEM licensing, so to my original question, what is the primary usage for you (I assume lending to daughter is a feature and not regular course)

        • Randy M says:
          January 22, 2020 at 1:57 pm

          She was watching a movie on it since my computer appears to be the last DVD capable device in the house, although I’m not sure I’m willing to pay for that in a new one. There’s a removable DVD player floating around our house somewhere.
          I don’t have a need for a very advanced computer, but I’d like to be able to play, say, XCOM 2 if I find it on sale. Mostly it’s used for word processing & internet browsing, streaming and so forth.
          I used to play Path of Exile, but at some point their upgrade broke it on my PC.

          • DragonMilk says:
            January 22, 2020 at 2:18 pm

            Do you use one or two monitors? Here, I’m thinking if you use one monitor, a prebuilt computer may be good enough. If multiple, then picking your own graphics card could help with performance.

          • Randy M says:
            January 22, 2020 at 2:29 pm

            Two monitors? The reverse, actually. I have both the PC and the game console hooked up to one monitor and switch between them.
            Space and price are concerns.

        • voso says:
          January 22, 2020 at 2:24 pm

          Regarding the legitimate copy of Windows, currently, Microsoft is still allowing you to activate Windows 10 with a Windows 7 or 8 key, and probably will let you do this forever, as they are pushing to reduce their OS fragmentation. There are a ton of <$10 keys of these floating around (and cheap Windows 10 keys that you find are probably these as well, since they're functionally the same).

          I wouldn't value Genuine Windows at more than $5, and it certainly shouldn't be a consideration for a build.

    • Jake R says:
      January 22, 2020 at 12:27 pm

      I built a PC about 15 years ago. The hardware was pretty straightforward with multiple tools to help make sure you got compatible parts, and assembly took maybe an hour. It then took about 3 weeks and tons of googling to get the BIOS configured and get windows installed. Maybe we did something horribly wrong, but has this been anyone else’s experience? If yes, has there been any improvement in user-friendliness here? I’d like to build another one but I’m reluctant to deal with that again.

      • DragonMilk says:
        January 22, 2020 at 12:38 pm

        Motherboard comes with BIOS preloaded and you can download windows 10 and never activate it (that’s what I’ve done so far) if you don’t mind a watermark telling you to please activate

      • Matt M says:
        January 22, 2020 at 12:40 pm

        Yeah, maybe I got lucky or something – but when I did this, I plugged everything in and it… just worked. First try. No sweat.

      • Conrad Honcho says:
        January 22, 2020 at 1:43 pm

        One very nice thing about the pcpartpicker.com website I linked is it will tell you if there’s any incompatibility between parts you select, so that’s one more way things have gotten easier in the last 15 years.

        If you pick out what you want and post them here I’ll look it over for you (and I’m sure others will as well). I’ve built a lot of computers.

      • Eltargrim says:
        January 23, 2020 at 11:54 am

        I recently built a PC. I didn’t realize that I’d need to flash the motherboard BIOS to get the full performance out of the Ryzen 5 processor. The first attempt went alright, but testing revealed that the motherboard had a bad RAM slot. Newegg RMA’d the mobo. Flashing the new mobo was fairly simple, very google-able, and worked just fine.

        I’d say that hardware installation is about as easy as 15 years ago, if not easier, but there’s a greater risk of hardware incompatibilities; be quite careful while selecting parts. I also suggest pcpartpicker.com for that.

        • Jake R says:
          January 23, 2020 at 1:35 pm

          I’m not sure what “flashing the motherboard BIOS” means and it’s those things that discourage me from trying to build one again.

          • anonymousskimmer says:
            January 23, 2020 at 1:54 pm

            From what I recall flashing the BIOS boils down to double clicking an executable, and then very carefully following the instructions to refrain from disconnecting the power until the software upgrade is complete.

          • John Schilling says:
            January 23, 2020 at 2:14 pm

            First, make sure you’ve chosen the proper executable.

          • Jake R says:
            January 23, 2020 at 2:37 pm

            How do you double-click an executable without an operating system or a hard drive? I believe that was the issue I ran into before, the mobo was not recognizing the hard drive.

          • Eltargrim says:
            January 23, 2020 at 2:40 pm

            Flashing the BIOS means updating from, e.g., v1.1 to v1.2.

            anonymousskimmer and John have basically got the right of it: make sure that you’ve chosen the right update file, and make sure the process doesn’t get interrupted, because unlike a bad OS installation you can’t just wipe the hard drive and start over.

            In my case, I very carefully downloaded a very particular file from the motherboard’s manufacturer’s website, and loaded it onto a USB stick. I then restarted the computer and launched into the BIOS. The BIOS interface then walked me through the process: have the USB stick in, pick the right file, read the warnings to not disconnect the power during the process, then hit confirm.

            I then waited for the process to complete, restarted the computer, re-launched the BIOS, and selected the RAM speed that I was trying to get to. Fairly straightforward, all told.

            I could have avoided literally all of the trouble by checking part compatibility. My check was basically “right socket? Should be fine.” 5 minutes of googling told me what the problem was, and what the solution was. If I had spent the 5 minutes googling first, I wouldn’t have had the problem in the first place.

          • Another Throw says:
            January 23, 2020 at 5:15 pm

            It is becoming increasingly common (though still generally an upmarket feature) for motherboards to have two copies of the BIOS, and automatically fail over to the backup if you screw up an upgrade or you choose incompatible settings or whatever.

            If it concerns you enough, and the price difference is small enough, you could pick one with that feature.

  50. Bobobob says:
    January 22, 2020 at 10:34 am

    Does anyone here think the Riemann Hypothesis might actually be false? I’ve read all three books on the subject (by far the best was John Derbyshire’s) and as convincing as the “pro” evidence seems to be, there are apparently some reputable mathematicians on the other side.

    What would it imply for our conception of reality if a mathematical proposition were “true” for the first googolplex instances, and then suddenly “not true?” (My understanding is that the earliest the Riemann Hypothesis could go awry is somewhere in that range.) It seems counter-intuitive to me, I would hope the universe is more euphoniously arranged.

    • Nick says:
      January 22, 2020 at 10:43 am

      What would it imply for our conception of reality if a mathematical proposition were “true” for the first googolplex instances, and then suddenly “not true?” (My understanding is that the earliest the Riemann Hypothesis could go awry is somewhere in that range.) It seems counter-intuitive to me, I would hope the universe is more euphoniously arranged.

      There are already interesting conjectures that wound up that way, like the Pólya conjecture. Does that offend your intuitions about reality? 🙂

      • Bobobob says:
        January 22, 2020 at 10:47 am

        Aha, but that counterexample came in at just under a billion, which is infinitesimal compared to the projected counterexample for the RH. (Although granted, at 10>361 the calculated upper bound is pretty big.)

        • hnrq says:
          January 22, 2020 at 11:28 am

          There are other conjectures that were falsified for very large numbers, the largest I know of:

          https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skewes%27s_number

          But very large numbers do appear in other places in mathematics, most famous of them being Graham’s number. Just as an example, it could be that there is some unknown connection between the Riemman hypothesis and the mathematics that lead to graham’s number. It does seem unlikely, but not impossible. Also, you have to consider how big the space of infinity is, it might lead to a very weird “coincidence” that only happens when a lot of things line up perfectly.

          • Bobobob says:
            January 22, 2020 at 11:32 am

            Skewe’s number is directly related to RH. It’s the point on a graph (if I recall correctly) where Riemann’s formula overcounts rather than undercounts the amount of primes up to a given number.

            But (again not being a mathematician) that sort of counterexample seems very different from a counterexample to RH, even though it’s fulsomely discussed in all of the RH books as pointing to how unpredictable incredibly (or unpredictably incredible) large prime numbers can be.

          • Kindly says:
            January 22, 2020 at 4:29 pm

            Both Skewes’s number and Graham’s number are upper bounds on when something happens; their size is an artifact of the proof methods, not of mathematical reality.

    • Dacyn says:
      January 22, 2020 at 12:43 pm

      RH has only been checked up to 10^13, nowhere near a googolplex.

      Anyway, I assign pretty high probability to RH, but not as much as e.g. P != NP. I’m not really sure why a counterexample would mean anything for our “conception of reality”, though.

      • viVI_IViv says:
        January 22, 2020 at 6:42 pm

        It would be funny if the standard Collatz conjecture was shown to be undecidable.

        • Noah says:
          January 22, 2020 at 9:20 pm

          According to http://people.cs.uchicago.edu/~simon/RES/collatz.pdf (which I have not read), the natural generalization of Collatz where you replaced even/odd with the value mod n for some n is in fact undecidable.

          • Dacyn says:
            January 23, 2020 at 10:14 am

            Both what you just said and what they state in their paper are in my opinion inaccurate or at least misleading ways of summarizing their results. What they prove is that there is no algorithm which inputs n and outputs the solution to the nth generalized Collatz problem. This does not imply that the generalization of the Collatz conjecture “all generalized Collatz problems eventually converge to 1” is undecidable (in fact, this generalization can be shown to be false), nor that for every n, the nth generalized Collatz problem is undecidable (which would imply that the Collatz problem itself is undecidable).

            It does imply that there exists an n such that the nth generalized Collatz problem is undecidable.

        • Dacyn says:
          January 23, 2020 at 10:20 am

          I suspect that the Collatz conjecture is undecidable, but also that we will never prove it to be so. Basically there is a heuristic argument which suggests that it is probably true, but no matter how far you compute, there is still a nonzero probability that it is false. The only way to decide it would be to take advantage of other relevant structure to the problem, which may or may not exist. But if you wanted to prove it doesn’t exist, you would need to take advantage of some other, probably nonexistent, form of structure…

          Anyway, it’s funny you mention because the Riemann hypothesis actually cannot be proven undecidable: if it is undecidable, it is true, and so if we proved it was undecidable, we can prove it is true, which means it is decidable. However, the Collatz conjecture is slightly more complicated so it avoids this.

          • caudectomie says:
            January 23, 2020 at 11:50 am

            Definitely a change of roles to say that the Riemann hypothesis is less complicated than the Collatz conjecture! The Collatz conjecture, after all, is often introduced—unabridged—to mere schoolchildren as an example of a particularly “simple” problem that has completed confounded mathematicians. Meanwhile, the Riemann hypothesis takes at least an advanced undergraduate education to properly formulate.

            In the end, of course, you are correct that the Riemann hypothesis is in a relevant sense logically simpler than the Collatz conjecture, namely by something like Robin’s theorem which renders it equivalent to a statement about the halting or non-halting of a certain Turing machine. Such a reduction does not (yet) exist for the Collatz conjecture.

          • Dacyn says:
            January 23, 2020 at 12:40 pm

            @caudectomie: Yeah maybe I could have phrased that better 🙂

          • viVI_IViv says:
            January 24, 2020 at 7:10 am

            In the end, of course, you are correct that the Riemann hypothesis is in a relevant sense logically simpler than the Collatz conjecture, namely by something like Robin’s theorem which renders it equivalent to a statement about the halting or non-halting of a certain Turing machine.

            Interesting, thanks for pointing out.

  51. johan_larson says:
    January 22, 2020 at 10:17 am

    The standard pack of playing cards is an idiosyncratic mess.
    – There are thirteen card ranks, but four suits. That’s a weird ratio. It’s not square. It’s not the golden ratio. It’s just lopsided. Sad!
    – Numbering starts at two. Sad!
    – Four cards in each suit don’t have numbers, but do have ranks. Sad!
    – The cards don’t have an obvious total ordering. Sad!

    Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to redesign the standard pack of playing cards to just plain make more sense.

    • Randy M says:
      January 22, 2020 at 10:24 am

      Ideally the deck would be built for game, to give the odds you want for whatever you were playing with, rather than with mathematical beauty in mind.
      That said, I like a deck of sixty, with 5 suits of twelve. Sixty is a good number, evenly divisible by 2,3,4,5, or 6.

      • Well... says:
        January 22, 2020 at 12:15 pm

        Ideally the deck would be built for game

        Why is that ideal? I want a deck I can use to play many different games. I don’t want to have to go buy a new deck for every game I might want to play. That would probably cause me to just never learn any but one or two games.

        • Randy M says:
          January 22, 2020 at 12:20 pm

          It seems more reasonable to me to design all the components with the experience you want in mind, rather than take a component and try to design a game around it. The former would be more likely to get you want you want.

          Cardstock is cheap, I don’t think price or storage is a concern. And imo, better to have a few perfect games than half a dozen that can be played pretty well around the deck you have.

          Though Nick’s argument that a game that evolved over time is going to fit very well to the deck it currently uses is a fine one.

          • Well... says:
            January 22, 2020 at 7:00 pm

            But it’s not just that I can play poker, solitaire, gin rummy, etc. all with the same deck of cards; I’m also familiar with this deck of cards and so is just about everyone else I’m likely to meet. It’s got an obvious pattern and internal consistency to it, as well as some intuitive symmetries though not as many as you’d like apparently.

            Consider this an applied version of Nick’s argument.

    • Nick says:
      January 22, 2020 at 10:27 am

      Go back to drawing evenly-spaced rectangular grids, you High Modernist! The deck arose from an organic process and is perfectly suited to its purposes.

      (Incidentally, I’m amazed your complaints don’t include the Joker.)

      • johan_larson says:
        January 22, 2020 at 10:38 am

        Enjoy toiling in the fields of your lord, like your father before you and your sons after you, you reactionary!

      • Machine Interface says:
        January 22, 2020 at 10:51 am

        Well, games tend to be made for the deck more than the other way around, because it’s easier to convince people to learn a new set of rules than to use unfamiliar cards. The dominance of the “French” (standard) deck of card is, like many things, a founder effect and a cultural accident — many regions of the world still use moderatedly or significantly different decks for their local games.

        And even standard decks have variation. Tarot games require tarot decks which expands beyond the 56 cards by adding knights and 22 trump cards. In the other direction some games are played with “stripped decks” with a number of cards removed (some of form of poker can be played with decks going as low as 20 cards – just 10, J, Q, K, A in each suit).

      • Le Maistre Chat says:
        January 22, 2020 at 12:24 pm

        (Incidentally, I’m amazed your complaints don’t include the Joker.)

        There’s a joke in there somewhere about how we shouldn’t have lost the Knights from the tarot deck, since that means there aren’t two dark Knights to oppose the Joker.

    • eyeballfrog says:
      January 22, 2020 at 10:28 am

      13:4 is one of the convergents of twice the golden ratio.

      • Nick says:
        January 22, 2020 at 10:33 am

        Which is just to say that 13:8 is one of the convergents. A lot of card games actually require two decks, hence eight suits, too.

    • Nornagest says:
      January 22, 2020 at 11:42 am

      Buy a set of mahjong tiles, the cards will look a lot better by comparison.

      • Nick says:
        January 22, 2020 at 11:48 am

        I watched Akagi last year and dear God, the game of mahjong is stupidly complicated.

        • Machine Interface says:
          January 22, 2020 at 1:29 pm

          Well it’s like Tarot or Bridge — the core of the game is a really simple idea that you can find in many other games (mahjong is basically a distant relative of rummy), but there’s a bunch of weird ritualistic stuff especially in the set up phase and in the jargon that make the game really opaque to non-initiates.

          I’ve several times tried to learn the rules of Tarot and each time got frustrated at how cabbalistic, esoteric and obtuse it all is, even though this is just a trick-taking game like Hearts or Spades, the rules of which can be learned in 2 minutes.

          • Enkidum says:
            January 22, 2020 at 2:32 pm

            I wouldn’t even say it’s a distant relative of Rummy – it is essentially identical to Rummy, with the addition of slightly different numbers of tiles per suit, and a whole set of arbitrary high-scoring hands.

        • BBA says:
          January 23, 2020 at 5:51 am

          And that’s just one local variant. We have monthly mahjong games at my office, but since all the experienced players came in knowing different rules, we just play a massively simplified version. Order some dim sum, wash it down with Tsingtao beer, fun all around.

          Under American rules everyone gets a helpful scorecard listing all the winning hands and their values. But these combinations change annually, and you have to buy new cards from the National Mah Jongg League every year. Nice racket they’ve got going there.

    • Le Maistre Chat says:
      January 22, 2020 at 12:21 pm

      – There are thirteen card ranks, but four suits. That’s a weird ratio. It’s not square. It’s not the golden ratio. It’s just lopsided. Sad!
      – Numbering starts at two. Sad!
      – Four cards in each suit don’t have numbers, but do have ranks. Sad!
      – The cards don’t have an obvious total ordering. Sad!

      • johan_larson says:
        January 22, 2020 at 1:20 pm

        There are many things going on, but I have an ample staff, so I can delegate nearly everything. Unfortunately no one in the White House is an authority on card game design, so this bit I’ll have to handle myself. Shouldn’t be a problem for a stable genius like me.

    • Dacyn says:
      January 22, 2020 at 12:35 pm

      Four suits (standard), four colors (red, yellow, green, blue), four ranks (1,2,3,4), for 64 cards. Total ordering is lexicographic (rank, color, suit), where we standardize the bridge ordering of suits (spades>hearts>diamonds>clubs). Or come up with new suits, the old ones might not work as well once they’re no longer distinguished by color.

      Now we just need to make up a game to play! (Well, that and find a cure for colorblindness…)

      • Nick says:
        January 22, 2020 at 12:44 pm

        Now we just need to make up a game to play!

        A game? A well designed deck will produce dozens of games. Here’s three whose rules wouldn’t change at all, though difficulty would change:
        #1: Memory
        #2 Solitaire
        #3 Spider Solitaire

        But the real trick is finding games that are the right difficulty. My impression from playing a lot of solitaire games—and I should really sit down and try to justify this mathematically—is that adding suits makes some games easier and other games harder, but making suits bigger (as I expect would happen with your game, if we have to stack, say, spades red 1-4, spades yellow 1-4, spades green etc. into one stack) usually makes games harder.

      • johan_larson says:
        January 22, 2020 at 12:50 pm

        Would a rummy-like game where that allows melds of three or more along any single value in any of the three dimensions (so three hearts, or three yellows, or three 2’s) would be better or worse than the original?

    • meh says:
      January 22, 2020 at 1:10 pm

      – The cards don’t have an obvious total ordering. Sad!

      In many games they do (bridge). Besides, what fun would the card game War be with a total ordering?

      • johan_larson says:
        January 23, 2020 at 2:00 am

        “Our new Patriot(TM) brand playing cards replace the jacks, queens, and kings by mayors, governors, and presidents, and the spades, clubs, hearts, and diamonds by stars, stripes, muskets, and the blood of tyrants.”

      • AlphaGamma says:
        January 23, 2020 at 2:15 am

        The only surviving use of the Greek word ρήγας, a hellenization of Latin rex, is for the king in a pack of cards.

        During the Byzantine empire, it was used to refer to foreign kings, as βασιλεύς, which was the more usual word for kings in ancient times, was reserved for the Emperor. In Modern Greek, βασιλεύς (with spelling changes) is again the generic word for ”king”. Foreign emperors are referred to as Aυτοκράτορας (the other part of the Byzantine Emperor’s title, “Autocrat”).

        Of course, I think ρήγας has survived on playing cards because the Greek words for them come from French- the queen and jack are ντάμα and βαλές, which are simply loans from Dame and Valet.

    • BBA says:
      January 23, 2020 at 5:38 am

      Obvious counterarguments – aces are ones, though only a few games still treat them as such. And lack of overall ordering is a feature, not a bug.

      There’s the 57-card Rook deck – cards numbered 1 to 14 in four colors, plus a “rook” wild card. It was marketed towards Christian communities that banned “standard” playing cards for their use in gambling and/or references to the occult, but I’ve seen it for sale in secular stores. Being Jewish, I suppose I should also mention the kvitlech deck once used in Jewish communities, a suitless 24-card deck in which there are two each of numbers 1 to 12.

      The 48-card Spanish deck (a more “regular” number) is numbered 1 to 12 in four suits. The spot cards are 1 to 9 and the face cards are 10 to 12, so essentially it’s a standard Anglo-French deck without the tens. So the casino blackjack variant called “Spanish 21” which is played with multiple tenless decks is actually a reference to something that exists, and not just a made up marketing name.

      • AlphaGamma says:
        January 23, 2020 at 6:18 am

        There are also the Japanese decks. Kabufuda has 4 identical sets of 10 cards numbered 1 to 9 plus a face card (and no suits), while hanafuda has 12 suits of 4 cards each.

        • Machine Interface says:
          January 23, 2020 at 6:49 am

          It’s interesting to note that Kabufuda are derived from Portuguese playing cards, and then when those were banned due to their use in gambling, the much more different hanafuda were created to get around the ban — apparently this happened multiple times; the Japanese government would ban a specific card set to prevent its easy manufacture and use in gambling, and of course gamblers and manufacturers would just come up with a new pattern/design.

  52. Matt M says:
    January 22, 2020 at 10:17 am

    Theory – the future of social media mob activity is going to be less “remove offending posts” and more “prevent offending posts from being removed.”

    It seems to me that when someone posts something offensive on Twitter and starts to get mobbed for it, the most likely immediate response by that person is to delete the offending post themselves and lock their account. Meanwhile, the people upset about the post rush to screenshot it and distribute it far and wide.

    I predict that at some point, the companies themselves will adopt a similar disciplinary strategy. If you post something inappropriate, the result won’t be “Twitter deletes it” but rather “Twitter prevents you from deleting it,” so that your misbehavior is on display in the town square for all to see.

    Am I crazy, or am I on to something here?

    • NoRandomWalk says:
      January 22, 2020 at 10:44 am

      Posts are ‘offensive’ if people with high status say they are. The way you exert high status is by getting other people to do stuff.

      Because what’s ‘offensive’ and who has ‘power’ changes so quickly, maintaining an ongoing demand that the same something stays up for a prolonged period of time is A) harder, and B) less effective because it staying up won’t ‘remain offensive’ for long.

      • John Schilling says:
        January 22, 2020 at 12:20 pm

        The way you exert high status is by getting other people to do stuff.

        By being seen to get other people to do stuff. If Alice doesn’t post something because she was afraid of what Bob would do, that may reflect Bob’s existing status but doesn’t give him any new status. If Alice posts something and Bob makes her (or her platform) take it down, that gives Bob status but without enduring visibility. If Alice posts something, Bob makes her take it down, and then Bob posts a screenshot under his own Twitter handle and leads the outrage mob that hounds Alice for having ever posted that thing, that may be the winning status move for Bob.

        • Matt M says:
          January 22, 2020 at 12:39 pm

          Right. The way to display status is to impose your will on others. This can be done by deleting posts that the other person wants to remain up. But my point is that increasingly, there reaches a certain point wherein the original poster shifts their preference from “I want this up” to “I want this hidden and for everyone to forget about it.”

          And at that point, the higher status party would demonstrate their higher status not by removing the post, but by requiring that it *not* be removed.

          • Le Maistre Chat says:
            January 22, 2020 at 12:46 pm

            The way to display status is to impose your will on others.

            I’m amused by the implication that libertarians can’t gain or display status.

          • NoRandomWalk says:
            January 22, 2020 at 12:49 pm

            Hm? Libertarians just object to violence as a mechanism. We like status games as much as anybody.

          • Guy in TN says:
            January 22, 2020 at 3:01 pm

            And at that point, the higher status party would demonstrate their higher status not by removing the post, but by requiring that it *not* be removed.

            When Scott removes a post or bans a poster, do you think he does this in order to display “higher status”?

            I question both assumptions contain here:
            1. That displaying administrative power over a website is the same things as displaying social status
            2. That webmasters are wielding this power only for purposes of displaying it

          • Matt M says:
            January 23, 2020 at 5:54 am

            When Scott removes a post or bans a poster, do you think he does this in order to display “higher status”?

            No, but I also think that Scott is somewhat uniquely fair-minded in a way that others are not.

            Scott does what he does in order to display transparency. I think it should be non-controversial to claim that transparency is not a particularly high value among Facebook and Twitter execs…

            Further, I think if a user made a post they very much regretted, even if Scott had already banned them, and if they emailed Scott and said “Hey, I’m sorry for that post, I deeply regret making it, could you please remove it?” that Scott would probably do so.

        • anonymousskimmer says:
          January 22, 2020 at 12:51 pm

          The way to display status is to impose your will on others.

          Not for the royal family.

          but by requiring that it *not* be removed.

          We’ve got copyright throughout the world. You can make a case for the first sale doctrine allowing this, but not in a context where the original producer of said copyrighted work had (and assumed they would always have) the right to remove said work.

    • Guy in TN says:
      January 22, 2020 at 10:50 am

      There are advantages/disadvantages to both methods, and the appropriateness of each method will depend on what sort of offense the post in question contains. For example, when Scott bans someone he often leaves the ban-worthy post up, and linked, as a testimony of “this is what he was banned for”. Although I am sure he also edits/removes posts that, for example, might contain someone’s home address.

      So why doesn’t Twitter or Facebook adopt the same policy? Why do they only remove posts? I suspect it has to do with the larger organization having to follow a more formal set of rules. Their policy is that “we will not host content that contains x”, not “we will not host content that contains x, except for the first time someone posts it, at our discretion”.

      I can see why, with the orders of magnitude more posts and users (and bots), they would choose to follow the former rule instead of the latter.

  53. kruasan says:
    January 22, 2020 at 9:52 am

    Is there any proper research on why do people have different musical tastes? Different genetics and different environments? How much of it is heritable? Where exactly is it encoded in the brain, and can you even tell if two people have the same tastes, just by looking at a neurological level?

    • helloo says:
      January 22, 2020 at 11:00 am

      Plenty of work has been done on musical tastes, though the ones I know are of a lower level questions that what you have.

      For example – some parts of music seem universal while others seem to be culturally dependent.

      This article describes of humans from a remote village that have rather different preferences to certain chords. (ie. they may prefer minor to major chords) https://doi.org/10.1038/nature18635

      While some music cues/moods, seem to be universal- https://mp.ucpress.edu/content/17/1/43

      Additionally, some people don’t seem to like music at all – https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Musical_anhedonia

        • Randy M says:
          January 22, 2020 at 9:52 am

          Preferably about what characters fighting the formic wars like to eat.

        • bean says:
          January 22, 2020 at 1:47 pm

          Hmm. I could. Or I could refuse to acknowledge his existence. Decisions, decisions….

          More seriously, @Beans, welcome. Just don’t be surprised if you get questions about battleships.

    • DragonMilk says:
      January 22, 2020 at 12:00 pm

      Now are you a bean expert?

      For instance, I usually put black and kidney beans in chili. Should I do otherwise?

      • Well... says:
        January 22, 2020 at 12:22 pm

        I don’t have Beans as a handle, but I am a big fan of the food and consider my palate for it somewhat refined. I would not recommend black beans for anything if other beans are available, unless you’re using them for burgers, because they have the least flavor.

        Kidney beans are fantastic. In a chili I would also approve of pintos, limas, and/or Great Northerns/canellinis.

  55. Lodore says:
    January 22, 2020 at 9:15 am

    I was talking to a biologist colleague at work the other day. Not having much else in common, I asked him about some topics in exobiology that interested me–in particular, the possibility of life on Europa, the Jovian moon. He was pretty sceptical, saying that there wasn’t enough of an energy gradient in the Europan ocean to make it likely.

    Here’s the thing: I’ve heard a lot about Europa as a potential home for life over the years, but not being a biologist, I can’t really assess how much of this is wishful thinking. The confidence with which my colleague disposed of the topic made me wonder if there’s a professional consensus here that I’m not hearing about because it isn’t newsworthy. I mean I know it’s not likely there’s life there, but ‘not likely’ is not the same as ‘as good as impossible’.

    Any biologists (exo or otherwise) want to clarify the situation?

    • herbert herberson says:
      January 22, 2020 at 9:33 am

      I’m no biologist, but now that we’ve drilled into subglacial Antarctic lakes I think we have a very clear test case for what could be possible in Europa. To wit–life, but not a lot of it, and probably only microscopic.

      • Lodore says:
        January 22, 2020 at 9:49 am

        I’m no biologist, but now that we’ve drilled into subglacial Antarctic lakes I think we have a very clear test case for what could be possible in Europa. To wit–life, but not a lot of it, and probably only microscopic.

        This is a reasonable ecological comparator, but I wonder could life ever have evolved independently in the Antarctic lakes? That might be more cognate to the Europan scenario.

    • Bobobob says:
      January 22, 2020 at 10:28 am

      My impression is that any prospective life in Europa’s oceans would be fueled by tidal activity. Imagine if the Earth’s oceans were pushed and pulled by Jupiter rather than the moon.

      • John Schilling says:
        January 22, 2020 at 12:27 pm

        For biology, you need energy in quanta potent enough to rearrange molecular bonds. That’s easy to get from visible-light photons, or it can come from preexisting energetic chemistry, but it’s hard to see how it comes from thermal gradients due to tidal heating.

        • D0TheMath says:
          January 22, 2020 at 1:30 pm

          The tidal heating doesn’t just cause thermal gradients. It also causes convection currents, and volcanic activity. The convection currents take minerals from the sea floor upwards, allowing easy access to raw materials for any life that forms, and the volcanic activity would serve as a fine energy source for any life that forms.

          By far, the strongest evidence in Europa’s favor is that it’d only ever take a single stable self-replicating cell to create life, as the sea is protected from radiation and comets by a large ice wall. From what I’ve heard, the Earth had to evolve life twice due to lots of asteroids hitting it at one point.

          The strongest evidence against is that Europa’s oceans are incredibly deep, which means the bottom must have tremendous pressure built up. The bottom would also be where the volcanic activity happens, so anything that becomes life would have to start out able to withstand that high of a pressure.

          It’s unlikely that there’s life on Europa, but not quite as unlikely as you think.

    • Bobobob says:
      January 22, 2020 at 10:42 am

      From Wikipedia. I hadn’t known about this:

      “The Hubble Space Telescope acquired an image of Europa in 2012 that was interpreted to be a plume of water vapour erupting from near its south pole.[92][91] The image suggests the plume may be 200 km (120 mi) high, or more than 20 times the height of Mt. Everest.[16][93][94] It has been suggested that if they exist, they are episodic[95] and likely to appear when Europa is at its farthest point from Jupiter, in agreement with tidal force modeling predictions.[96] Additional imaging evidence from the Hubble Space Telescope was presented in September 2016.[97][98]”

    • drunkfish says:
      January 22, 2020 at 2:57 pm

      There probably aren’t whales chilling in the ocean, but at the ocean floor you have water interacting with (potentially hot) rock so at least locally you should be able to get pretty huge thermal and potentially chemical gradients. Your biologist friend may be skeptical about the ability to start up life there, which is definitely beyond me, but sustaining life on Europa’s sea floor doesn’t strike me as being particularly harder than sustaining life at black smokers on Earth, which is clearly possible.

      Something to consider is why we talk about Europa so much at all. Europa has much less liquid water than Ganymede (any maybe Callisto? I’m not sure) and *vastly* less total water (liquid+ice) than Ganymede or Callisto. I think the reason we focus on Europa so much over the other two is that Europa uniquely (among the three moons) is expected to have liquid water in contact with rock. I think that at least shows that the focus on Europa has at least some grounding in reality and the people talking about biology on Europa have thought through the need for a heat/chemical source at the base of the ocean.

      If you asked me to bet on it at even odds, I’d bet against Europa having life, but I don’t think it’s implausible at all.

      (Note I’m not a biologist, I’m a planetary scientist working some on Europa from a geophysics perspective)

    • Ketil says:
      January 23, 2020 at 12:44 am

      He was pretty sceptical, saying that there wasn’t enough of an energy gradient in the Europan ocean to make it likely.

      What does this mean? I understand you need energy for life, but gradient? Is it an argument about entropy, like a Stirling/heat engine needing a difference in temperatures to work?

      • fibio says:
        January 23, 2020 at 2:10 am

        Pretty much. At its core cell biology is just chemistry, you need high energy inputs and low energy outputs. Photons also work well as a high energy input source. Sugars are event better if you can get them. Standing between a hot and cold surface would maybe be viable but the number of locations on earth where the difference is wide enough to matter on a cellular level is pretty low. A pH gradient might do in a pinch as well.

    • Concavenator says:
      January 23, 2020 at 4:44 am

      From what I can tell, the field seems split between very optimistic and very pessimistic people on that matter, and both kinds are very confident in their position. There’s plenty of clever proposals (for example; also see Irwin & Schulze-Makuch’s work) on how life might work in different biochemical environments, but in the end we still know very little about how life arose in the first place. If the origin of life is relatively likely and not an incredibly contrived stroke of luck, then Europa seems a decent candidate. (Also Enceladus, which seems rather similar to Europa, and Titan, which makes for some very interesting speculation with its lakes of liquid methane.)
      Here are some proposals for Europan life (summarized from Irwin and Schulze-Makuch). One I like is an osmotrophic organism that cycles between the seafloor (where vents enrich the water with minerals) and the seatop (where melting ice dilutes it), or simply grows through the column like colossal kelp, exploiting the difference in salt concentration (water flows into the organism at the top and out at the bottom, driving some kind of molecular “motor”). Europa’s ocean is kilometers deep, though – and I don’t think we have hard data on what the concentration gradient really is.

          • Conrad Honcho says:
            January 22, 2020 at 12:10 pm

            I’ve played all three games and read all the books and watched the show.

            The show is fairly faithful to the books, although a lot of plot points are jumbled up, partly because they jump around between three different time periods without any indication that’s what they’re doing. I understood what was going on because I knew what the characters were doing and when, but I had to explain it to my wife.

            Yenn in the show is true to books: she was ugly and used magic to make herself hot, and sorceresses are sterile.

            While I’m sympathetic to the whole “woke crowd takes something We White Men love, kills it, and wears its skin suit to push socio-political propaganda” thing when it comes to something like Star Wars, the Witcher was never a “right wing” or “traditional” series. It was always about racist humans who colonized elven and dwarven lands, oppressed them, and obliterated their cultures. It was always about the rape and subjugation of the earth and the destruction of natural habitats. This is really not any sort of Culture War hill to die on.

            That said, yeah they make lots of people inexplicably black. Particularly I’m thinking of the captain of the guards (or perhaps the Queen’s bodyguard?) of Cintra. Cintra is a kingdom, not an empire. I expect all the people there to be of related stock. So seeing him I’m wondering if he’s a foreigner, who has some interesting backstory about how he came to Cintra and rose through the ranks? Or is Cintra now multiethnic? That stuff I find jarring. And of course the Nilfgaardian bad guys are all white, even though it would make more sense for them to be multiethnic because they’re an empire: their army should be made up of not just Nilfgaardians but the people they conquered.

            And yes, Matt, that scene is there. Just roll your eyes and move on. The show is definitely worth watching, especially for Henry Cavill’s excellent performance. Oh, and the whole Toss a Coin to Your Witcher cover phenomenon.

            ETA: @Milo

            By the end of the season, it seems like women are the main drivers of the plot, not to mention a majority of the most powerful in-setting characters.

            The first two Witcher books were collections of short stories about Geralt. Once you get into the big plot arc in the later books, Ciri is arguably a more important character.

          • anonymousskimmer says:
            January 22, 2020 at 12:23 pm

            @Matt M

            So, not as woke as I thought, but maybe less original? (That plot point seems pretty heavily ripped off from the Red Woman in GoT?)

            This plot point takes less than a minute of time, and has no further bearing on the plot. It’s not a plot point, it’s a minor scene.

            @ConradHoncho

            That said, yeah they make lots of people inexplicably black.

            Given the manner in which skin color shows up, it seems to only make sense if it passes through the population the same way hair color (or straightness/thickness) does. This isn’t Earth’s human skin color genetics.

        • Ketil says:

          I saw the series, and I am usually put off when current-day wokeness is blatantly shoehorned into places it doesn’t fit. Didn’t react negatively to anything here.

          • Matt M says:
            January 23, 2020 at 6:17 am

            Thanks. I think the applause was really the kicker for me. It’s like a literal re-creation of the “… and then everyone clapped” Twitter meme.

          • Conrad Honcho says:
            January 23, 2020 at 7:05 am

            I can see why the scene you refer to (inter-racial intercourse followed by applause) looks weird when taken out of context, but it does’t come across as wokeness (nor the opposite) – unless you think inter-racial sexual relations is a no-no.

            I think it’s more like “graphic depictions of interracial sexual relations” or “changing established characters races to make a sexual relationship interracial” signals wokeness, because the woke crowd has decided interracial sex is a moral good, and believe it tweaks off their political opponents. It’s a Culture War flag planting.

            I don’t have a problem with IR relationships. Love is love, whatever. I don’t think they’re bad, worthy of discouraging, but also don’t think they’re a moral good, worthy of promoting. I just don’t care one way or the other, but having the woke writers specifically present this to me, changing the characters so they can say “look how good this is! Now don’t say anything or that means you’re a bigot!” makes me roll my eyes.

            Imagine Christianity makes a cultural comeback, and now writing rooms are staffed by Evangelical Christians. They get their hands on the Star Trek license and reboot TNG.

            Now, in this world, the non-believers and agnostics are still out there, and are pretty much like they are today: they don’t think religion or Christianity is bad, per se, it’s just not their thing. If other people enjoy their faith and it makes them happy and they live longer and have happier lives because of it, great, it’s just not for them.

            Well our new evangelical writers want to “update” TNG to conform to the new moral good. So now all the characters are also evangelical christians. Not in any way that screws with the plots, it’s just sort of…there in the background. So you have a completely standard episode, like the Enterprise encounters a space anomaly, and trapped inside are two alien ships, who could work together to get out, but they hate each other, and the crew is in a race against time to either find a technical solution to the problem, or get the aliens to set aside their differences before they’re both destroyed.

            Now, in the new TNG, instead of the cold open being the officers playing poker when the set shakes and the watch calls everyone to the bridge because they ran into the anomaly, they’re doing bible study. That silly Data understands the words of the proverbs, but he takes them literally instead of understanding their deeper meaning!

            Later when they visit Picard’s ready room his cross is on conspicuous display next to all his little model ships.

            At some point they seek assistance from a nearby Starfleet vessel, the USS Pat Robertson.

            I’m sure agnostic or non-christian Star Trek fans would be fine with that. After all, they don’t really have any problem with Christianity. It’s all fine, just not their thing. It’s Star Trek, with space anomalies and aliens and moral dilemmas, and Picard and Riker and Data and all that, and the christian messaging isn’t important to the plot. Only anti-christian bigots would take to the internet to complain that the writers changed the characters in nonsensical ways to suit their own social politics, and we’d have news articles about how “anti-christian bigot trolls” are review bombing the new TNG because they hate Jesus.

          • Randy M says:
            January 23, 2020 at 7:36 am

            That actually sounds pretty interesting–though I’d object to it in Star Trek, as that’s clearly not the vision of it’s creators, Sci-fi in general is too quick to assume secular enlightenment descends on humanity the moment the first star ship is finished.

            As to your actual point, there seems to occasionally be an intentionality to the interracial pairings that I find off-putting in ways that I don’t object to in real life. Maybe because it communicates (or, charitably, I read it as) a tacit message that there’s an element of bigotry in the much more common homogeneous pairings. Annoying when we’re told that other groups sexual preferences are immutable, innate, and worth celebrating.
            The counter point that they are just trying to market to a wider audience by including leads of multiple demographics does probably explain much of this, though.

      • Conrad Honcho says:
        January 22, 2020 at 12:34 pm

        lacks a cohesive plot outside the Ciri story.

        I kind of wish it didn’t have a cohesive plot at all. My favorite thing about the Witcher franchise is not the overarching “gotta save the world” story but the Witcher as Magic Batman. Do it episodic monster-of-the-week instead. The Witcher shows up at village that’s called for help with a monster. The Witcher investigates, uses his knowledge of monsters to identify the beast and prepare his attack. He confronts the monster but not all is what it seems and he encounters Dark Secrets the villagers have been trying to hide. Morality play ensues. The matter resolved, the Witcher rides off into the sunset for next week’s adventure.

        The short stories were great. The side quests were the best part of Witcher 3. Batman doesn’t have to save the world to have a good Batman story. He just has to figure out what the Joker is up to and stop him before he robs another bank. Do that. I miss episodic rather than serial TV shows.

  57. rocoulm says:
    January 22, 2020 at 8:57 am

    It’s embarrassingly late to ask, but there’s one point on the impeachment discussion I’ve never been made clear on. Regarding the military aid Trump blocked, was the congressional involvement beforehand:

    (a) approval, i.e., some other part of the government expressed interest in sending aid and Congress okayed it, or

    (b) directional, i.e., Congress determined Ukraine should receive aid without any involvement of another part of the government

    • citizencokane says:
      January 22, 2020 at 9:39 am

      Correct me if I’m wrong, but this appears to be the original text of the appropriations bill:
      https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/115/hr6157/text/enr

      Here is, I think, the relevant part:

      9013.For the Ukraine Security Assistance Initiative, $250,000,000 is hereby appropriated, to remain available until September 30, 2019: Provided, That such funds shall be available to the Secretary of Defense, in coordination with the Secretary of State, to provide assistance, including training; equipment; lethal assistance; logistics support, supplies and services; sustainment; and intelligence support to the military and national security forces of Ukraine, and for replacement of any weapons or articles provided to the Government of Ukraine from the inventory of the United States: Provided further, That of the amounts made available in this section, $50,000,000 shall be available only for lethal assistance described in paragraphs (2) and (3) of section 1250(b) of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2016 (Public Law 114–92; 129 Stat. 1068): Provided further, That the Secretary of Defense shall, not less than 15 days prior to obligating funds provided under this heading, notify the congressional defense committees in writing of the details of any such obligation: Provided further, That the United States may accept equipment procured using funds provided under this heading in this or prior Acts that was transferred to the security forces of Ukraine and returned by such forces to the United States: Provided further, That equipment procured using funds provided under this heading in this or prior Acts, and not yet transferred to the military or National Security Forces of Ukraine or returned by such forces to the United States, may be treated as stocks of the Department of Defense upon written notification to the congressional defense committees: Provided further, That amounts made available by this section are designated by the Congress for Overseas Contingency Operations/Global War on Terrorism pursuant to section 251(b)(2)(A)(ii) of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985.
      9014.Funds appropriated in this title shall be available for replacement of funds for items provided to the Government of Ukraine from the inventory of the United States to the extent specifically provided for in section 9013 of this Act.
      9015.None of the funds made available by this Act under section 9013 may be used to procure or transfer man-portable air defense systems.

      The way I read this is that this bill made the funds available to the Secretary of Defense to be used for the general purposes listed, at the Secretary of Defense’s discretion. IFF the Secretary of Defense wished to put these funds to use, it looks like he/she was obligated to notify Congressional defense committees about the specific usage of the funds 15 days prior to the use of the funds. However, I don’t see anything in the bill about needing to notify Congress about a specific reason for NOT using the funds within a given timeframe.

      If it is ultimately up to the Secretary of Defense’s discretion to employ the funds, then is it not ultimately up to the President’s discretion? (Seeing as the President is the Commander in Chief and the SecDef’s superior?) Even if not, wouldn’t the Democrats have to prove that the President restrained the funds against the SecDef’s wishes?

      Am I reading the wrong bill?

      • anonymousskimmer says:
        January 22, 2020 at 9:48 am

        I’m bolding what I see as key words:

        9013.For the Ukraine Security Assistance Initiative, $250,000,000 is hereby appropriated, to remain available until September 30, 2019: Provided, That such funds shall be available to the Secretary of Defense, in coordination with the Secretary of State, to provide assistance, including training; equipment; lethal assistance; logistics support, supplies and services; sustainment; and intelligence support to the military and national security forces of Ukraine, and for replacement of any weapons or articles provided to the Government of Ukraine from the inventory of the United States: Provided further, That of the amounts made available in this section, $50,000,000 shall be available only for lethal assistance described in paragraphs (2) and (3) of section 1250(b) of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2016 (Public Law 114–92; 129 Stat. 1068): Provided further, That the Secretary of Defense shall, not less than 15 days prior to obligating funds provided under this heading, notify the congressional defense committees in writing of the details of any such obligation: Provided further, That the United States may accept equipment procured using funds provided under this heading in this or prior Acts that was transferred to the security forces of Ukraine and returned by such forces to the United States: Provided further, That equipment procured using funds provided under this heading in this or prior Acts, and not yet transferred to the military or National Security Forces of Ukraine or returned by such forces to the United States, may be treated as stocks of the Department of Defense upon written notification to the congressional defense committees: Provided further, That amounts made available by this section are designated by the Congress for Overseas Contingency Operations/Global War on Terrorism pursuant to section 251(b)(2)(A)(ii) of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985.
        9014.Funds appropriated in this title shall be available for replacement of funds for items provided to the Government of Ukraine from the inventory of the United States to the extent specifically provided for in section 9013 of this Act.
        9015.None of the funds made available by this Act under section 9013 may be used to procure or transfer man-portable air defense systems.

        The only phrasing that seems to give the secretary of defense any discretion is “notify the congressional defense committees in writing of the details of any such obligation”. It’s possible that “any such” is defined in the code in a way that doesn’t give discretion on the making of such obligations, but instead mandates that “every obligation, no matter how minor, including a 50 cent obligation for a single bullet” (as an example) be reported.

        The “shalls” and “to provide” seem to be non-discretionary. The “mays” are discretionary. IMO.

        According to NPR, the Impoundment Control Act, which specifies that the President has obligations to report to Congress, which he did not do in a timely manner, is the crux of the dereliction of duty claims:

        SEC. 1012. (a) TRANSMITTAL OF SPECIAL MESSAGE.—Whenever the President determines that all or part of any budget authority will not be required to carry out the full objectives or scope of programs for which it is provided or that such budget authority should be rescinded for fiscal policy or other reasons (including the termination of author-ized projects or activities for which budget authority has been pro-vided), or whenever all or part of budget authority provided for only one fiscal year is to be reserved from obligation for such fiscal year, the President shall transmit to both Houses of Congress a special message specifying—

        As President he has legal obligations. If he had left this up to SecDef to determine he may not have had an issue. But he intervened, and he is only allowed to intervene if he fulfills his obligations for such intervention.

        • citizencokane says:
          January 22, 2020 at 9:58 am

          But how does the word “available” not imply discretion? If it had said, …”such funds shall be employed by the Secretary of Defense, in coordination with the Secretary of State, to provide assistance, including training; equipment; lethal assistance; logistics support, supplies and services…” then I could see your point.

          To me, the “shall” part specifies that the funds will be made available to the Secretary of Defense, no ifs, ands, or buts. But it doesn’t say that the Secretary of Defense has to immediately employ the funds.

          In fact, the part about the 15-day notification implies that the Secretary of Defense is to use discretion as to the decision of how (or whether) to use the funds for any specific purpose, and must clear any such discretional decision with congressional defense committees prior to doing so.

          EDIT: The President’s failure to notify Congress in a timely manner that he did not plan on using the funds right away (or at all, unless the Ukraine met certain conditions that may or may not be in the US’s national interest or Trump’s personal interests) does seem like a slam-dunk. Trump should have notified Congress that, “I’m not giving Ukraine the funds until they clean up their act. It’s a bad place. A lot of bad people there. American taxpayer money goes to waste. All the time. It’s a disgrace. One example is the Biden family. Ukraine needs to investigate them again and make sure taxpayer money is not finding its way into their corrupt pockets.” If Trump had said something like that, he would be on more solid ground right now.

          • anonymousskimmer says:
            January 22, 2020 at 10:04 am

            The word “available” is Congress ordering another party (most likely the treasury) to provide these funds to the SecDef.

            I’ve edited my original comment to indicate that the President himself has special duties that the SecDef may not have (though the original bills making the SecDef position may itself mandate what the SecDef can and cannot legally do). And that it is the dereliction of these duties by the President that is the issue here, not the freezing of funds per se.

            and must clear any such discretional decision with congressional defense committees prior to doing so.

            All it said is that the SecDef has to report these things to them, not clear it with them.

          • citizencokane says:
            January 22, 2020 at 10:12 am

            This comment I found on a news site implies that Congress is holding Trump to an isolated demand for rigor:

            No biggie, this was known some 5 months ago. Violation of the Impound Act is not a criminal offense and carries no penalty. It was a technical timeline violation and the aid was paid. In government, these technical timeline violations occur with some frequency …

            In 2011 the GAO ruled that Obama violated both the Impound Act and the Antideficiency Act.

            And what about Congress??:
            “In fiscal years 2017 to 2019 alone, OMB said, congressional committees directed that billions of dollars in State and U.S. Agency for International Development funds be withheld for 10 days or more beyond a typically 15-day statutory notice period after Congress is notified of an intent to obligate funds.

            For example, in fiscal 2017, the letter says, congressional committee holds of State and USAID funds included one hold of 321 days, one of 228 days, and three holds of more than 100 days past the statutory notice period. The budget office said there were at least 115 instances of congressionally directed holds in foreign aid funds in fiscal 2017 that extended 10 or more days past the statutory notice period.”

          • John Schilling says:
            January 22, 2020 at 12:09 pm

            Violation of the Impound Act is not a criminal offense and carries no penalty. It was a technical timeline violation and the aid was paid.

            The aid was paid only after Trump had been made aware of the impending whistleblower report (which was held up in the executive branch for several weeks while the bureaucracy dithered about whether they had to forward it to congress).

            As a mitigating factor, that’s right up there with an embezzler returning the money after he learns the police are asking his friends pointed questions about him.

            Whether a mitigating factor is needed, depends on whether you are willing to write off the underlying offense as a “technicality”. Not making payment on schedule, probably just a technicality. Trying to weasel out of paying at all, maybe not a technicality depending on circumstances. Delaying or withholding payment as part of a clumsy extortion plot, probably not a technicality.

      • rocoulm says:
        January 22, 2020 at 9:52 am

        Thanks, this’ll give me some reading up to do.

    • anonymousskimmer says:
      January 22, 2020 at 9:40 am

      With all federal budget matters you get chicken and egg issues, because each chamber of Congress has their own idea, and the executive branch has its own requests as well.

      American lawmakers from the Democratic and Republican parties, at least as far back as 2015, have been urging the United States to help Ukraine with arms and other heavy military equipment to defend itself against Russian-backed separatists.

      One irony is that the Trump administration was going further with its aid than the Obama administration by deciding to provide Ukraine with lethal weapons. In 2017, Trump announced his intent to provide the Javelin, and Congress approved an assistance package of 210 missiles and 37 launchers, together worth $47 million.

      I’m not going to read further, but this article has a lot of background: https://www.defensenews.com/congress/2019/09/25/what-you-need-to-know-about-the-us-aid-package-to-ukraine-that-trump-delayed/

    • J Mann says:
      January 22, 2020 at 12:02 pm

      The GAO lays out the basic facts in their opinion, although not everyone agrees with their conclusion.

      Basically:

      – Congress appropriated $250 million, with the money to be distributed after the DOD certified that Ukraine had taken substantial action on reforms and before September 30. DOD certified that in May.

      – From July 25-September 10, Office of Management and Budget released several schedules that didn’t include the money, and did include footnotes saying they were holding the money for now, and would pause until some date in the future (but always before September 30).

      – GAO concluded that if the White House wanted to put a hold on the funds, they were required to notify Congress of a “deferral,”

      This isn’t my area, so I may just have missed it, but I’m not quite sure by what date GAO believes Trump was obligated to confirm he would be sending the money – since he had until September 30 to do it, is GAO saying he was required to obligate it in his first letter, or by some specific date?

      • Clutzy says:
        January 22, 2020 at 1:35 pm

        The GAO opinion, to me, is a good start to a legal opinion, but I’ve found some points in it that don’t really come together:

        1) Not sure their discussion of 2 U.S.C. § 684 makes sense. Thus its not clear what they mean on this issue. Did Trump have to report to withhold, or merely did he have to report a suspicion that he might?

        2) There is a lot of mindreading in the opinion, that’s simply not good law. Its rarely even circumstantial mindreading with evidence, mostly just pure mindreading.

        3) The deadline was actually met so its unclear who can object legally in a US court. This is not important for impeachment, but should be if we are to be expected to trust GAO. Instead they issued an opinion that doesn’t indicate a remedy. This is not becoming for something that is supposed to be a serious legal opinion.

        4) A failing to discuss whether this is a process problem (e.g. delay may have been proper if they did things properly under #1) or a substantive problem (even if they crossed all the Ts and dotted the Is this was a violation). This is particularly relevant for the Trump admin because they are continually plagued with staffing problems and soft insubordination by the GS-10-15s who don’t agree with him.

        • J Mann says:
          January 22, 2020 at 2:51 pm

          Yeah, the thing that I think the GAO leaves unanswered is: when is the President required to obligate apportioned funds:

          1) Whenever the agency in question asks for it?
          2) Sufficiently before the end of the fiscal year to allow the funds to be spent?
          3) Sometime before the end of the fiscal year?

          If the President wasn’t required to obligate the funds at all, then I’m not sure he was required to declare a deferral, but maybe GAO has thought about that.

          Worth mentioning – around that time, the White House was holding up another 4 billion in foreign aid related spending, so it’s not like that wasn’t something they did as a matter of course.

        • sharper13 says:
          January 22, 2020 at 7:30 pm

          The ICA specifies a remedy for violation by the OMB (which is who the GAO report actually states did something wrong, it merely “implies” Trump is indirectly to blame because it was his foreign policy involved). There’s nothing criminal involved, the ICA authorizes a civil lawsuit to compel the OMB to release the funds. As the funds were actually released, even that remedy is legally moot.

          As others have pointed out, the OMB delaying payment like this and the GAO complaining in a report is a routine occurrence, happening about once a year on average over multiple administrations.

          Also, I should point out that the GAO’s legal opinion on the matter of what’s permissible is closely tied to Congress, as they are an agency of Congress. Their opinion isn’t binding on the Executive Branch and the Executive branch has a long-held legal opinion (supported by a USSC case) that the President is allowed to delay foreign aide as a result of his sole power regarding foreign policy. The exact limitations of that would have to be argued in court, but it’s not as clear-cut as some might imagine.

    • Log in

  • Subscribe via Email

  • Advertisements

  • Beeminder's an evidence-based willpower augmention tool that collects quantifiable data about your life, then helps you organize it into commitment mechanisms so you can keep resolutions. They've also got a blog about what they're doing here

    AISafety.com hosts a Skype reading group Wednesdays at 19:45 UTC, reading new and old articles on different aspects of AI Safety. We start with a presentation of a summary of the article, and then discuss in a friendly atmosphere.

    The Effective Altruism newsletter provides monthly updates on the highest-impact ways to do good and help others.

    MealSquares is a "nutritionally complete" food that contains a balanced diet worth of nutrients in a few tasty easily measurable units. Think Soylent, except zero preparation, made with natural ingredients, and looks/tastes a lot like an ordinary scone.

    The COVID-19 Forecasting Project at the University of Oxford is making advanced pandemic simulations of 150+ countries available to the public, and also offer pro-bono forecasting services to decision-makers.

    Support Slate Star Codex on Patreon. I have a day job and SSC gets free hosting, so don't feel pressured to contribute. But extra cash helps pay for contest prizes, meetup expenses, and me spending extra time blogging instead of working.

    Substack is a blogging site that helps writers earn money and readers discover articles they'll like.

    Metaculus is a platform for generating crowd-sourced predictions about the future, especially science and technology. If you're interested in testing yourself and contributing to their project, check out their questions page

    Giving What We Can is a charitable movement promoting giving some of your money to the developing world or other worthy causes. If you're interested in this, consider taking their Pledge as a formal and public declaration of intent.

    Altruisto is a browser extension so that when you shop online, a portion of the money you pay goes to effective charities (no extra cost to you). Just install an extension and when you buy something, people in poverty will get medicines, bed nets, or financial aid.

    Dr. Laura Baur is a psychiatrist with interests in literature review, reproductive psychiatry, and relational psychotherapy; see her website for more. Note that due to conflict of interest she doesn't treat people in the NYC rationalist social scene.

    80,000 Hours researches different problems and professions to help you figure out how to do as much good as possible. Their free career guide show you how to choose a career that's fulfilling and maximises your contribution to solving the world's most pressing problems.

    Seattle Anxiety Specialists are a therapy practice helping people overcome anxiety and related mental health issues (eg GAD, OCD, PTSD) through evidence based interventions and self-exploration. Check out their free anti-anxiety guide here

    .

    The Charter Cities Institute is working on ways governments can set up special zones with unique legal institutions. Learn more about how this could help tackle problems from global poverty to climate change.

    B4X is a free and open source developer tool that allows users to write apps for Android, iOS, and more.

    Norwegian founders with an international team on a mission to offer the equivalent of a Norwegian social safety net globally available as a membership. Currently offering travel medical insurance for nomads, and global health insurance for remote teams.

    Jane Street is a quantitative trading firm with a focus on technology and collaborative problem solving. We're always hiring talented programmers, traders, and researchers and have internships and fulltime positions in New York, London, and Hong Kong. No background in finance required.
